chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:1
verses.text: The Stromata, or Miscellanies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:2
verses.text: Book 4   Chapter I.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:3
verses.text: —Order of Contents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:4
verses.text: It will follow, I think, that I should treat of martyrdom, and of who the perfect man is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:5
verses.text: With these points shall be included what follows in accordance with the demands of the points to be spoken about, and how both bond and free must equally philosophize, whether male or female in sex.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:6
verses.text: And in the sequel, after finishing what is to be said on faith and inquiry, we shall set forth the department of symbols; so that, on cursorily concluding the discourse on ethics, we shall exhibit the advantage which has accrued to the Greeks from the barbarian philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:7
verses.text: After which sketch, the brief explanation of the Scriptures both against the Greeks and against the Jews will be presented, and whatever points we were unable to embrace in the previous Miscellanies (through having respect necessarily to the multitude of matters), in accordance with the commencement of the poem, purposing to finish them in one commentary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:8
verses.text: In addition to these points, afterwards on completing the sketch, as far as we can in accordance with what we propose, we must give an account of the physical doctrines of the Greeks and of the barbarians, respecting elementary principles, as far as their opinions have reached us, and argue against the principal views excogitated by the philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:9
verses.text: It will naturally fall after these, after a cursory view of theology, to discuss the opinions handed down respecting prophecy; so that, having demonstrated that the Scriptures which we believe are valid from their omnipotent authority, we shall be able to go over them consecutively, and to show thence to all the heresies one God and Omnipotent Lord to be truly preached by the law and the prophets, and besides by the blessed Gospel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:10
verses.text: Many contradictions against the heterodox await us while we attempt, in writing, to do away with the force of the allegations made by them, and to persuade them against their will, proving by the Scriptures themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:11
verses.text: On completing, then, the whole of what we propose in the commentaries, on which, if the Spirit will, we ministering to the urgent need, (for it is exceedingly necessary, before coming to the truth, to embrace what ought to be said by way of preface), shall address ourselves to the true gnostic science of nature, receiving initiation into the minor mysteries before the greater; so that nothing may be in the way of the truly divine declaration of sacred things, the subjects requiring preliminary detail and statement being cleared away, and sketched beforehand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:12
verses.text: The science of nature, then, or rather observation, as contained in the gnostic tradition according to the rule of the truth, depends on the discussion concerning cosmogony, ascending thence to the department of theology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:13
verses.text: Whence, then, we shall begin our account of what is handed down, with the creation as related by the prophets, introducing also the tenets of the heterodox, and endeavouring as far as we can to confute them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 1:14
verses.text: But it shall be written if God will, and as He inspires; and now we must proceed to what we proposed, and complete the discourse on ethics.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—The Meaning of the Name Stromata or Miscellanies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:2
verses.text: Let these notes of ours, as we have often said for the sake of those that consult them carelessly and unskilfully, be of varied character—and as the name itself indicates, patched together—passing constantly from one thing to another, and in the series of discussions hinting at one thing and demonstrating another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:3
verses.text: "For those who seek for gold," says Heraclitus, "dig much earth and find little gold".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:4
verses.text: But those who are of the truly golden race, in mining for what is allied to them, will find the much in little.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:5
verses.text: For the word will find one to understand it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:6
verses.text: The Miscellanies of notes contribute, then, to the recollection and expression of truth in the case of him who is able to investigate with reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:7
verses.text: And you must prosecute, in addition to these, other labours and researches; since, in the case of people who are setting out on a road with which they are unacquainted, it is sufficient merely to point out the direction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:8
verses.text: After this they must walk and find out the rest for themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:9
verses.text: As, they say, when a certain slave once asked at the oracle what he should do to please his master, the Pythian priestess replied, "You will find if you seek".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:10
verses.text: It is truly a difficult matter, then, as turns out, to find out latent good; since  "Before virtue is placed exertion, And long and steep is the way to it, And rough at first; but when the summit is reached, Then is it easy, though difficult before".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:11
verses.text: "For narrow," in truth, "and strait is the way" of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:12
verses.text: And it is to the "violent that the kingdom of God belongs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:13
verses.text: Whence, "Seek, and ye shall find," holding on by the truly royal road, and not deviating.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:14
verses.text: As we might expect, then, the generative power of the seeds of the doctrines comprehended in this treatise is great in small space, as the "universal herbage of the field," as Scripture saith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:15
verses.text: Thus the Miscellanies of notes have their proper title, wonderfully like that ancient oblation culled from all sorts of things of which Sophocles writes:—  "For there was a sheep's fleece, and there was a vine, And a libation, and grapes well stored; And there was mixed with it fruit of all kinds, And the fat of the olive, and the most curious Wax-formed work of the yellow bee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:16
verses.text: Just so our Stromata, according to the husbandman of the comic poet Timocles, produce "figs, olives, dried figs, honey, as from an all-fruitful field;" on account of which exuberance he adds:—  "Thou speakest of a harvest-wreath not of husbandry".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:17
verses.text: For the Athenians were wont to cry:—  "The harvest-wreath bears figs and fat loaves, And honey in a cup, and olive oil to anoint you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 2:18
verses.text: We must then often, as in winnowing sieves, shake and toss up this the great mixture of seeds, in order to separate the wheat.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—The True Excellence of Man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:2
verses.text: The most of men have a disposition unstable and heedless, like the nature of storms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:3
verses.text: "Want of faith has done many good things, and faith evil things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:4
verses.text: And Epicharmus says, "Don't forget to exercise incredulity; for it is the sinews of the soul".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:5
verses.text: Now, to disbelieve truth brings death, as to believe, life; and again, to believe the lie and to disbelieve the truth hurries to destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:6
verses.text: The same is the case with self-restraint and licentiousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:7
verses.text: To restrain one's self from doing good is the work of vice; but to keep from wrong is the beginning of salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:8
verses.text: So the Sabbath, by abstinence from evils, seems to indicate self-restraint.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:9
verses.text: And what, I ask, is it in which man differs from beasts, and the angels of God, on the other hand, are wiser than he? "Thou madest him a little lower than the angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:10
verses.text: For some do not interpret this Scripture of the Lord, although He also bore flesh, but of the perfect man and the gnostic, inferior in comparison with the angels in time, and by reason of the vesture of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:11
verses.text: I call then wisdom nothing but science, since life differs not from life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:12
verses.text: For to live is common to the mortal nature, that is to man, with that to which has been vouchsafed immortality; as also the faculty of contemplation and of self-restraint, one of the two being more excellent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:13
verses.text: On this ground Pythagoras seems to me to have said that God alone is wise, since also the apostle writes in the Epistle to the Romans, "For the obedience of the faith among all nations, being made known to the only wise God through Jesus Christ;" and that he himself was a philosopher, on account of his friendship with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:14
verses.text: Accordingly it is said, "God talked with Moses as a friend with a friend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:15
verses.text: That, then, which is true being clear to God, forthwith generates truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:16
verses.text: And the gnostic loves the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:17
verses.text: "Go," it is said, "to the ant, thou sluggard, and be the disciple of the bee;" thus speaks Solomon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:18
verses.text: For if there is one function belonging to the peculiar nature of each creature, alike of the ox, and horse, and dog, what shall we say is the peculiar function of man? He is like, it appears to me, the Centaur, a Thessalian figment, compounded of a rational and irrational part, of soul and body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:19
verses.text: Well, the body tills the ground, and hastes to it; but the soul is raised to God: trained in the true philosophy, it speeds to its kindred above, turning away from the lusts of the body, and besides these, from toil and fear, although we have shown that patience and fear belong to the good man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:20
verses.text: For if "by the law is the knowledge of sin," as those allege who disparage the law, and "till the law sin was in the world;" yet "without the law sin was dead," we oppose them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:21
verses.text: For when you take away the cause of fear, sin, you have taken away fear; and much more, punishment, when you have taken away that which gives rise to lust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:22
verses.text: "For the law is not made for the just  man," says the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:23
verses.text: Well, then, says Heraclitus, "They would not have known the name of Justice if these things had not been".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:24
verses.text: And Socrates says, "that the law was not made for the sake of the good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:25
verses.text: But the cavillers did not know even this, as the apostle says, "that he who loveth his brother worketh not evil;" for this, "Thou shalt not kill, thou shalt not commit adultery, thou shalt not steal; and if there be any other commandment, it is comprehended in the word, Thou shall love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:26
verses.text: So also is it said, "Thou shall love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:27
verses.text: And "if he that loveth his neighbour worketh no evil," and if "every commandment is comprehended in this, the loving our neighbour," the commandments, by menacing with fear, work love, not hatred.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:28
verses.text: Wherefore the law is productive of the emotion of fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:29
verses.text: "So that the law is holy," and in truth "spiritual," according to the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:30
verses.text: We must, then, as is fit, in investigating the nature of the body and the essence of the soul, apprehend the end of each, and not regard death as an evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:31
verses.text: "For when ye were the servants of sin," says the apostle, "ye were free from righteousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:32
verses.text: What fruit had ye then in those things in which ye are now ashamed? For the end of those things is death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:33
verses.text: But now, being made free from sin, and become servants to God, ye have your fruit unto holiness, and the end everlasting life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:34
verses.text: For the wages of sin is death: but the gift of God is eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:35
verses.text: The assertion, then, may be hazarded, that it has been shown that death is the fellowship of the soul in a state of sin with the body; and life the separation from sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:36
verses.text: And many are the stakes and ditches of lust which impede us, and the pits of wrath and anger which must be overleaped, and all the machinations we must avoid of those who plot against us,—who would no longer see the knowledge of God "through a glass".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:37
verses.text: "The half of virtue the far-seeing Zeus takes From man, when he reduces him to a state of slavery".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:38
verses.text: As slaves the Scripture views those "under sin" and "sold to sin," the lovers of pleasure and of the body; and beasts rather than men, "those who have become like to cattle, horses, neighing after their neighbours' wives".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:39
verses.text: The licentious is "the lustful ass," the covetous is the "savage wolf," and the deceiver is "a serpent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:40
verses.text: The severance, therefore, of the soul from the body, made a life-long study, produces in the philosopher gnostic alacrity, so that he is easily able to bear natural death, which is the dissolution of the chains which bind the soul to the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 3:41
verses.text: "For the world is crucified to me, and I to the world," the apostle says; "and now I live, though in the flesh, as having my conversation in heaven".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—The Praises of Martyrdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:2
verses.text: Whence, as is reasonable, the gnostic, when Galled, obeys easily, and gives up his body to him who asks; and, previously divesting himself of the affections of this carcase, not insulting the tempter, but rather, in my opinion, training him and convincing him,—  "From what honour and what extent of wealth fallen,"  as says Empedocles, here for the future he walks with mortals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:3
verses.text: He, in truth, bears witness to himself that he is faithful and loyal towards God; and to the tempter, that he in vain envied him who is faithful through love; and to the Lord, of the inspired persuasion in reference to His doctrine, from which he will not depart through fear of death; further, he confirms also the truth of preaching by his deed, showing that God to whom he hastes is powerful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:4
verses.text: You will wonder at his love, which he conspicuously shows with thankfulness, in being united to what is allied to him, and besides by his precious blood, shaming the unbelievers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:5
verses.text: He then avoids denying Christ through fear by reason of the command; nor does he sell his faith in the hope of the gifts prepared, but in love to the Lord he will most gladly depart from this life; perhaps giving thanks both to him who afforded the cause of his departure hence, and to him who laid the plot against him, for receiving an honourable reason which he himself furnished not, for showing what he is, to him by his patience, and to the Lord in love, by which even before his birth he was manifested to the Lord, who knew the martyr's choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:6
verses.text: With good courage, then, he goes to the Lord, his friend, for whom he voluntarily gave his body, and, as his judges hoped, his soul, hearing from our Saviour the words of poetry, "Dear brother," by reason of the similarity of his life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:7
verses.text: We call martyrdom perfection, not because the man comes to the end of his life as others, but because he has exhibited the perfect work of love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:8
verses.text: And the ancients laud the death of those among the Greeks who died in war, not that they advised people to die a violent death, but because he who ends his life in war is released without the dread of dying, severed from the body without experiencing previous suffering or being enfeebled in his soul, as the people that suffer in diseases.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:9
verses.text: For they depart  in a state of effeminacy and desiring to live; and therefore they do not yield up the soul pure, but bearing with it their lusts like weights of lead; all but those who have been conspicuous in virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:10
verses.text: Some die in battle with their lusts, these being in no respect different from what they would have been if they had wasted away by disease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:11
verses.text: If the confession to God is martyrdom, each soul which has lived purely in the knowledge of God, which has obeyed the commandments, is a witness both by life and word, in whatever way it may be released from the body,—shedding faith as blood along its whole life till its departure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:12
verses.text: For instance, the Lord says in the Gospel, "Whosoever shall leave father, or mother, or brethren," and so forth, "for the sake of the Gospel and my name," he is blessed; not indicating simple martyrdom, but the gnostic martyrdom, as of the man who has conducted himself according to the rule of the Gospel, in love to the Lord (for the knowledge of the Name and the understanding of the Gospel point out the gnosis, but not the bare appellation), so as to leave his worldly kindred, and wealth, and every possession, in order to lead a life free from passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:13
verses.text: "Mother" figuratively means country and sustenance; "fathers" are the laws of civil polity: which must be contemned thankfully by the high-souled just man; for the sake of being the friend of God, and of obtaining the right hand in the holy place, as the Apostles have done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:14
verses.text: Then Heraclitus says, "Gods and men honour those slain in battle;" and Plato in the fifth book of the Republic writes, "Of those who die in military service, whoever dies after winning renown, shall we not say that he is chief of the golden race? Most assuredly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:15
verses.text: But the golden race is with the gods, who are in heaven, in the fixed sphere, who chiefly hold command in the providence exercised towards men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:16
verses.text: Now some of the heretics who have misunderstood the Lord, have at once an impious and cowardly love of life; saying that the true martyrdom is the knowledge of the only true God (which we also admit), and that the man is a self-murderer and a suicide who makes confession by death; and adducing other similar sophisms of cowardice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:17
verses.text: To these we shall reply at the proper time; for they differ with us in regard to first principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:18
verses.text: Now we, too, say that those who have rushed on death (for there are some, not belonging to us, but sharing the name merely, who are in haste to give themselves up, the poor wretches dying through hatred to the Creator)—these, we say, banish themselves without being martyrs, even though they are punished publicly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:19
verses.text: For they do not preserve the characteristic mark of believing martyrdom, inasmuch as they have not known the only true God, but give themselves up to a vain death, as the Gymnosophists of the Indians to useless fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:20
verses.text: But since these falsely named calumniate the body, let them learn that the harmonious mechanism of the body contributes to the understanding which leads to goodness of nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:21
verses.text: Wherefore in the third book of the Republic, Plato, whom they appeal to loudly as an authority that disparages generation, says, "that for the sake of harmony of soul, care must be taken for the body," by which, he who announces the proclamation of the truth, finds it possible to live, and to live well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:22
verses.text: For it is by the path of life and health that we learn gnosis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:23
verses.text: But is he who cannot advance to the height without being occupied with necessary things, and through them doing what tends to knowledge, not to choose to live well? In living, then, living well is secured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 4:24
verses.text: And he who in the body has devoted himself to a good life, is being sent on to the state of immortality.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—On Contempt for Pain, Poverty, and Other External Things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:2
verses.text: Fit objects for admiration are the Stoics, who say that the soul is not affected by the body, either to vice by disease, or to virtue by health; but both these things, they say, are indifferent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:3
verses.text: And indeed Job, through exceeding continence, and excellence of faith, when from rich he became poor, from being held in honour dishonoured, from being comely unsightly, and sick from being healthy, is depicted as a good example, putting the Tempter to shame, blessing his Creator; bearing what came second, as the first, and most clearly teaching that it is possible for the gnostic to make an excellent use of all circumstances.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:4
verses.text: And that ancient achievements are proposed as images for our correction, the apostle shows, when he says, "So that my bonds in Christ are become manifest in all the palace, and to all the rest; and several of the brethren in the Lord, waxing confident by my bonds, are much more bold to speak the word of God without fear,"—since martyrs' testimonies are examples of conversion gloriously sanctified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:5
verses.text: "For what things the Scripture speaks were written for our instruction, that we, through patience and the consolation of the Scriptures, might have the hope of consolation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:6
verses.text: When pain is present, the soul appears to decline from it, and to deem release from present pain a precious thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:7
verses.text: At that moment it slackens from studies, when the other virtues also are  neglected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:8
verses.text: And yet we do not say that it is virtue itself which suffers, for virtue is not affected by disease.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:9
verses.text: But he who is partaker of both, of virtue and the disease, is afflicted by the pressure of the latter; and if he who has not yet attained the habit of self-command be not a high-souled man, he is distraught; and the inability to endure it is found equivalent to fleeing from it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:10
verses.text: The same holds good also in the case of poverty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:11
verses.text: For it compels the soul to desist from necessary things, I mean contemplation and from pure sinlessness, forcing him, who has not wholly dedicated himself to God in love, to occupy himself about provisions; as, again, health and abundance of necessaries keep the soul free and unimpeded, and capable of making a good use of what is at hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:12
verses.text: "For," says the apostle, "such shall have trouble in the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:13
verses.text: But I spare you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:14
verses.text: For I would have you without anxiety, in order to decorum and assiduity for the Lord, without distraction".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:15
verses.text: These things, then, are to be abstained from, not for their own sakes, but for the sake of the body; and care for the body is exercised for the sake of the soul, to which it has reference.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:16
verses.text: For on this account it is necessary for the man who lives as a gnostic to know what is suitable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:17
verses.text: Since the fact that pleasure is not a good thing is admitted from the fact that certain pleasures are evil, by this reason good appears evil, and evil good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:18
verses.text: And then, if we choose some pleasures and shun others, it is not every pleasure that is a good thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:19
verses.text: Similarly, also, the same rule holds with pains, some of which we endure, and others we shun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:20
verses.text: But choice and avoidance are exercised according to knowledge; so that it is not pleasure that is the good thing, but knowledge by which we shall choose a pleasure at a certain time, and of a certain kind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:21
verses.text: Now the martyr chooses the pleasure that exists in prospect through the present pain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:22
verses.text: If pain is conceived as existing in thirst, and pleasure in drinking, the pain that has preceded becomes the efficient cause of pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:23
verses.text: But evil cannot be the efficient cause of good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:24
verses.text: Neither, then, is the one thing nor the other evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:25
verses.text: Simonides accordingly (as also Aristotle) writes, "that to be in good health is the best thing, and the second best thing is to be handsome, and the third best thing is to be rich without cheating".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:26
verses.text: And Theognis of Megara says:—  "You must, to escape poverty, throw Yourself, O Cyrnus down from The steep rocks into the deep sea".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:27
verses.text: On the other hand, Antiphanes, the comic poet, says, "Plutus (Wealth), when it has taken hold of those who see better than others, makes them blind".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:28
verses.text: Now by the poets he is proclaimed as blind from his birth:—  "And brought him forth blind who saw not the sun".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:29
verses.text: Says the Chalcidian Euphorion:—  "Riches, then, and extravagant luxuries, Were for men the worst training for manliness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:30
verses.text: Wrote Euripides in Alexander:—  "And it is said, Penury has attained wisdom through misfortune; But much wealth will capture not Sparta alone, but every city".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 5:31
verses.text: "It is not then the only coin that mortals have, that which is white silver or golden, but virtue too," as Sophocles says.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—Some Points in the Beatitudes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:2
verses.text: Our holy Saviour applied poverty and riches, and the like, both to spiritual things and objects of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:3
verses.text: For when He said, "Blessed are they that are persecuted for righteousness' sake," He clearly taught us in every circumstance to seek for the martyr who, if poor for righteousness' sake, witnesses that the righteousness which he loves is a good thing; and if he "hunger and thirst for righteousness' sake," testifies that righteousness is the best thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:4
verses.text: Likewise he, that weeps and mourns for righteousness' sake, testifies to the best law that it is beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:5
verses.text: As, then, "those that are persecuted," so also "those that hunger and thirst" for righteousness' sake, are called "blessed" by Him who approves of the true desire, which not even famine can put a stop to.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:6
verses.text: And if "they hunger after righteousness itself," they are blessed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:7
verses.text: "And blessed are the poor," whether "in spirit" or in circumstance"—that is, if for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:8
verses.text: It is not the poor simply, but those that have wished to become poor for righteousness' sake, that He pronounces blessed—those who have despised the honours of this world in order to attain "the good;" likewise also those who, through chastity, have become comely in person and character, and those who are of noble birth, and honourable, having through righteousness attained to adoption, and therefore "have received power to become the sons of God," and "to tread on serpents and scorpions," and to rule over demons and "the host of the adversary".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:9
verses.text: And, in fine, the Lord's discipline draws the soul away gladly from the body, even if it wrench itself away in its removal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:10
verses.text: "For he that loveth his life shall lose it, and he that loseth his life shall find it," if we only join that which is mortal of us with  the immortality of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:11
verses.text: It is the will of God that we should attain the knowledge of God, which is the communication of immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:12
verses.text: He therefore, who, in accordance with the word of repentance, knows his life to be sinful will lose it—losing it from sin, from which it is wrenched; but losing it, will find it, according to the obedience which lives again to faith, but dies to sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:13
verses.text: This, then, is what it is "to find one's life," "to know one's self".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:14
verses.text: The conversion, however, which leads to divine things, the Stoics say, is affected by a change, the soul being changed to wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:15
verses.text: And Plato: "On the soul taking a turn to what is better, and a change from a kind of nocturnal day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:16
verses.text: Now the philosophers also allow the good man an exit from life in accordance with reason, in the case of one depriving him of active exertion, so that the hope of action is no longer left him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:17
verses.text: And the judge who compels us to deny Him whom we love, I regard as showing who is and who is not the friend of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:18
verses.text: In that case there is not left ground for even examining what one prefers—the menaces of man or the love of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:19
verses.text: And abstinence from vicious acts is found, somehow, to result in the diminution and extinction of vicious propensities, their energy being destroyed by inaction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:20
verses.text: And this is the import of "Sell what thou hast, and give to the poor, and come, follow Me"—that is, follow what is said by the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:21
verses.text: Some say that by what "thou hast" He designated the things in the soul, of a nature not akin to it, though how these are bestowed on the poor they are not able to say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:22
verses.text: For God dispenses to all according to desert, His distribution being righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:23
verses.text: Despising, therefore, the possessions which God apportions to thee in thy magnificence, comply with what is spoken by me; haste to the ascent of the Spirit, being not only justified by abstinence from what is evil, but in addition also perfected, by Christlike beneficence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:24
verses.text: In this instance He convicted the man, who boasted that he had fulfilled the injunctions of the law, of not loving his neighbour; and it is by beneficence that the love which, according to the gnostic ascending scale, is Lord of the Sabbath, proclaims itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:25
verses.text: We must then, according to my view, have recourse to the word of salvation neither from fear of punishment nor promise of a gift, but on account of the good itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:26
verses.text: Such, as do so, stand on the right hand of the sanctuary; but those who think that by the gift of what is perishable they shall receive in exchange what belongs to immortality are in the parable of the two brothers called "hirelings".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:27
verses.text: And is there not some light thrown here on the expression "in the likeness and image," in the fact that some live according to the likeness of Christ, while those who stand on the left hand live according to their image? There are then two things proceeding from the truth, one root lying beneath both,—the choice being, however, not equal, or rather the difference that is in the choice not being equal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:28
verses.text: To choose by way of imitation differs, as appears to me, from the choice of him who chooses according to knowledge, as that which is set on fire differs from that which is illuminated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:29
verses.text: Israel, then, is the light of the likeness which is according to the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:30
verses.text: But the image is another thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:31
verses.text: What means the parable of Lazarus, by showing the image of the rich and poor? And what the saying, "No man can serve two masters, God and Mammon?"—the Lord so terming the love of money.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:32
verses.text: For instance, the covetous, who were invited, responded not to the invitation to the supper, not because of their possessing property, but of their inordinate affection to what they possessed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:33
verses.text: "The foxes," then, have holes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:34
verses.text: He called those evil and earthly men who are occupied about the wealth which is mined and dug from the ground, foxes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:35
verses.text: Thus also, in reference to Herod: "Go, tell that fox, Behold, I cast out devils, and perform cures to-day and to-morrow, and the third day I shall be perfected".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:36
verses.text: For He applied the name "fowls of the air" to those who were distinct from the other birds—those really pure, those that have the power of flying to the knowledge of the heavenly Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:37
verses.text: For not riches only, but also honour, and marriage, and poverty, have ten thousand cares for him who is unfit for them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:38
verses.text: And those cares He indicated in the parable of the fourfold seed, when He said that "the seed of the word which fell unto the thorns" and hedges was choked by them, and could not bring forth fruit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:39
verses.text: It is therefore necessary to learn how to make use of every occurrence, so as by a good life, according to knowledge, to be trained for the state of eternal life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:40
verses.text: For it said, "I saw the wicked exalted and towering as the cedars of Lebanon; and I passed," says the Scripture, "and, lo, he was not; and I sought him, and his place was not found.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:41
verses.text: Keep innocence, and look on uprightness: for there is a remnant to the man of peace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:42
verses.text: Such will he be who believes unfeignedly with his whole heart, and is tranquil in his whole soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:43
verses.text: "For the different people honour me with their lips, but their heart is far from the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:44
verses.text: "They bless  with their mouth, but they curse in their heart".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:45
verses.text: "They loved Him with their mouth, and lied to Him with their tongue; but their heart was not right with Him, and they were not faithful to His covenant".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:46
verses.text: Wherefore "let the false lips become speechless, and let the Lord destroy the boastful tongue: those who say, We shall magnify our tongue, and our lips are our own; who is Lord over us? For the affliction of the poor and the groaning of the needy now will I arise, saith the Lord; I will set him in safety; I will speak out in his case".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:47
verses.text: For it is to the humble that Christ belongs, who do not exalt themselves against His flock.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:48
verses.text: "Lay not up for yourselves, therefore, treasures on the earth, where moth and rust destroy, and thieves break through and steal," says the Lord, in reproach perchance of the covetous, and perchance also of those who are simply anxious and full of cares, and those too who indulge their bodies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:49
verses.text: For amours, and diseases, and evil thoughts "break through" the mind and the whole man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:50
verses.text: But our true "treasure" is where what is allied to our mind is, since it bestows the communicative power of righteousness, showing that we must assign to the habit of our old conversation what we have acquired by it, and have recourse to God, beseeching mercy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:51
verses.text: He is, in truth, "the bag that waxeth not old," the provisions of eternal life, "the treasure that faileth not in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:52
verses.text: "For I will have mercy on whom I will have mercy," saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:53
verses.text: And they say those things to those who wish to be poor for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:54
verses.text: For they have heard in the commandment that "the broad and wide way leadeth to destruction, and many there are who go in by it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:55
verses.text: It is not of anything else that the assertion is made, but of profligacy, and love of women, and love of glory, and ambition, and similar passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:56
verses.text: For so He says, "Fool, this night shall thy soul be required of thee; and whose shall those things be which thou hast prepared?" And the commandment is expressed in these very words, "Take heed, therefore, of covetousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:57
verses.text: For a man's life does not consist in the abundance of those things which he possesses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:58
verses.text: For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?" "Wherefore I say, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat; neither for your body, what ye shall put on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:59
verses.text: For your life is more than meat, and your body than raiment".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:60
verses.text: And again, "For your Father knoweth that ye have need of all these things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:61
verses.text: "But seek first the kingdom of heaven, and its righteousness," for these are the great things, and the things which are small and appertain to this life "shall be added to you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:62
verses.text: Does He not plainly then exhort us to follow the gnostic life, and enjoin us to seek the truth in word and deed? Therefore Christ, who trains the soul, reckons one rich, not by his gifts, but by his choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:63
verses.text: It is said, therefore, that Zaccheus, or, according to some, Matthew, the chief of the publicans, on hearing that the Lord had deigned to come to him, said, "Lord, and if I have taken anything by false accusation, I restore him fourfold;" on which the Saviour said, "The Son of man, on coming to-day, has found that which was lost".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:64
verses.text: Again, on seeing the rich cast into the treasury according to their wealth, and the widow two mites, He said "that the widow had cast in more than they all," for "they had contributed of their abundance, but she of her destitution".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:65
verses.text: And because He brought all things to bear on the discipline of the soul, He said, "Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:66
verses.text: And the meek are those who have quelled the battle of unbelief in the soul, the battle of wrath, and lust, and the other forms that are subject to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:67
verses.text: And He praises those meek by choice, not by necessity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:68
verses.text: For there are with the Lord both rewards and "many mansions," corresponding to men's lives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:69
verses.text: "Whosoever shall receive," says He, "a prophet in the name of a prophet, shall receive a prophet's reward; and whosoever shall receive a righteous man in the name of a righteous man, shall receive a righteous man's reward; and whoso shall receive one of the least of these my disciples, shall not lose his reward".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:70
verses.text: And again, the differences of virtue according to merit, and the noble rewards, He indicated by the hours unequal in number; and in addition, by the equal reward given to each of the labourers—that is, salvation, which is meant by the penny—He indicated the equality of justice; and the difference of those called He intimated, by those who worked for unequal portions of time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:71
verses.text: They shall work, therefore, in accordance with the appropriate mansions of which they have been deemed worthy as rewards, being fellow-workers in the ineffable administration and service.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:72
verses.text: "Those, then," says Plato, "who seem called to a holy life, are those who, freed and released from those earthly localities as from prisons, have reached the pure dwelling-place on high".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:73
verses.text: In clearer terms again he  expresses the same thing: "Those who by philosophy have been sufficiently purged from those things, live without bodies entirely for all time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:74
verses.text: Although they are enveloped in certain shapes; in the case of some, of air, and others, of fire".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:75
verses.text: He adds further: "And they reach abodes fairer than those, which it is not easy, nor is there sufficient time now to describe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:76
verses.text: Whence with reason, "blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted;" for they who have repented of their former evil life shall attain to "the calling" (κλῆσιν), for this is the meaning of being comforted (παρακληθῆναι).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:77
verses.text: And there are two styles of penitents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:78
verses.text: That which is more common is fear on account of what is done; but the other which is more special, the shame which the spirit feels in itself arising from conscience.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:79
verses.text: Whether then, here or elsewhere (for no place is devoid of the beneficence of God), He again says, "Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:80
verses.text: And mercy is not, as some of the philosophers have imagined, pain on account of others' calamities, but rather something good, as the prophets say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:81
verses.text: For it is said, "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:82
verses.text: And He means by the merciful, not only those who do acts of mercy, but those who wish to do them, though they be not able; who do as far as purpose is concerned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:83
verses.text: For sometimes we wish by the gift of money or by personal effort to do mercy, as to assist one in want, or help one who is sick, or stand by one who is in any emergency; and are not able either from poverty, or disease, or old age (for this also is natural disease), to carry out our purpose, in reference to the things to which we are impelled, being unable to conduct them to the end we wished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:84
verses.text: Those, who have entertained the wish whose purpose is equal, share in the same honour with those who have the ability, although others have the advantage in point of resources.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:85
verses.text: And since there are two paths of reaching the perfection of salvation, works and knowledge, He called the "pure in heart blessed, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:86
verses.text: And if we really look to the truth of the matter, knowledge is the purification of the leading faculty of the soul, and is a good activity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:87
verses.text: Some things accordingly are good in themselves, and others by participation in what is good, as we say good actions are good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:88
verses.text: But without things intermediate which hold the place of material, neither good nor bad actions are constituted, such I mean as life, and health, and other necessary things or circumstantials.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:89
verses.text: Pure then as respects corporeal lusts, and pure in respect of holy thoughts, he means those are, who attain to the knowledge of God, when the chief faculty of the soul has nothing spurious to stand in the way of its power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:90
verses.text: When, therefore, he who partakes gnostically of this holy quality devotes himself to contemplation, communing in purity with the divine, he enters more nearly into the state of impassible identity, so as no longer to have science and possess knowledge, but to be science and knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:91
verses.text: "Blessed, then, are the peacemakers," who have subdued and tamed the law which wars against the disposition of the mind, the menaces of anger, and the baits of lust, and the other passions which war against the reason; who, having lived in the knowledge both of good works and true reason, shall be reinstated in adoption, which is dearer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:92
verses.text: It follows that the perfect peacemaking is that which keeps unchanged in all circumstances what is peaceful; calls Providence holy and good; and has its being in the knowledge of divine and human affairs, by which it deems the opposites that are in the world to be the fairest harmony of creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:93
verses.text: They also are peacemakers, who teach those who war against the stratagems of sin to have recourse to faith and peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:94
verses.text: And it is the sum of all virtue, in my opinion, when the Lord teaches us that for love to God we must gnostically despise death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:95
verses.text: "Blessed are they," says He, "who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for they shall be called the sons of God;" or, as some of those who transpose the Gospels say, "Blessed are they who are persecuted by righteousness, for they shall be perfect".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:96
verses.text: And, "Blessed are they who are persecuted for my sake; for they shall have a place where they shall not be persecuted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 6:97
verses.text: And, "Blessed are ye when men shall hate you, when they shall separate you, when they shall cast out your name as evil, for the Son of man's sake;" if we do not detest our persecutors, and undergo punishments at their hands, not hating them under the idea that we have been put to trial more tardily than we looked for; but knowing this also, that every instance of trial is an occasion for testifying.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—The Blessedness of the Martyr.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:2
verses.text: Then he who has lied and shown himself unfaithful, and revolted to the devil's army, in what evil do we think him to be? He belies, therefore, the Lord, or rather he is cheated of his own hope who believes not God; and he believes not who does not what He has commanded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:3
verses.text: And what? Does not he, who denies the Lord, deny himself? For does he not rob his Master of His authority, who deprives himself of his relation to Him? He, then, who denies the Saviour, denies life; for "the light was life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:4
verses.text: He does not term those men of little faith, but faithless and hypocrites, who have the name inscribed on them, but deny that they are really believers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:5
verses.text: But the faithful is called both servant and friend.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:6
verses.text: So that if one loves himself, he loves the Lord, and confesses to salvation that he may save his soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:7
verses.text: Though you die for your neighbour out of love, and regard the Saviour as our neighbour (for God who saves is said to be nigh in respect to what is saved); you do so, choosing death on account of life, and suffering for your own sake rather than his.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:8
verses.text: And is it not for this that he is called brother? he who, suffering out of love to God, suffered for his own salvation; while he, on the other hand, who dies for his own salvation, endures for love to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:9
verses.text: For he being life, in what he suffered wished to suffer that we might live by his suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:10
verses.text: "Why call ye me Lord, Lord," He says, "and do not the things which I say?" For "the people that loveth with their lips, but have their heart far away from the Lord," is another people, and trust in another, and have willingly sold themselves to another; but those who perform the commandments of the Lord, in every action "testify," by doing what He wishes, and consistently naming the Lord's name; and "testifying" by deed to Him in whom they trust, that they are those "who have crucified the flesh, with the affections and lusts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:11
verses.text: "If we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:12
verses.text: "He that soweth to his flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption; but he that soweth to the Spirit, shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:13
verses.text: But to those miserable men, witness to the Lord by blood seems a most violent death, not knowing that such a gate of death is the beginning of the true life; and they will understand neither the honours after death, which belong to those who have lived holily, nor the punishments of those who have lived unrighteously and impurely.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:14
verses.text: I do not say only from our Scriptures (for almost all the commandments indicate them); but they will not even hear their own discourses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:15
verses.text: For the Pythagorean Theano writes, "Life were indeed a feast to the wicked, who, having done evil, then die; were not the soul immortal, death would be a godsend".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:16
verses.text: And Plato in the Phaedo, "For if death were release from everything," and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:17
verses.text: We are not then to think according to the Telephus of aeschylus, "that a single path leads to Hades".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:18
verses.text: The ways are many, and the sins that lead thither.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:19
verses.text: Such deeply erring ones as the unfaithful are, Aristophanes properly makes the subjects of comedy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:20
verses.text: "Come," he says, "ye men of obscure life, ye that are like the race of leaves, feeble, wax figures, shadowy tribes, evanescent, fleeting, ephemeral".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:21
verses.text: And Epicharmus, "This nature of men is inflated skins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:22
verses.text: And the Saviour has said to us, "The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:23
verses.text: "Because the carnal mind is enmity against God," explains the apostle: "for it is not subject to the law of God, neither indeed, can be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:24
verses.text: And they that are in the flesh cannot please God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:25
verses.text: And in further explanation continues, that no one may, like Marcion regard the creature as evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:26
verses.text: "But if Christ be in you, the body is dead because of sin; but the Spirit is life because of righteousness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:27
verses.text: And again: "For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:28
verses.text: For I reckon that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared to the glory which shall be revealed in us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:29
verses.text: If we suffer with Him, that we also may be glorified together as joint-heirs of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:30
verses.text: And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them that are called according to the purpose.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:31
verses.text: For whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate to be conformed to the image of His Son, that He might be the first-born among many brethren.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:32
verses.text: And whom He did predestinate, them He also called; and whom He called, them He also justified; and whom He justified, them He also glorified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:33
verses.text: You see that martyrdom for love's sake is taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:34
verses.text: And should you wish to be a martyr for the recompense of advantages, you shall hear again.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:35
verses.text: "For we are saved by hope: but hope that is seen is not hope: for what a man seeth, why doth he yet hope for? But if we hope for that we see not, then do we with patience wait for it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:36
verses.text: "But if we also suffer for righteousness' sake," says Peter, "blessed are we.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:37
verses.text: Be not afraid of their fear, neither be troubled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:38
verses.text: But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to him that asks a reason of the hope that is in you, but with meekness and fear, having a good conscience; so that in reference to that for which you are spoken against, they may be ashamed who calumniate your good conversation in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:39
verses.text: For it is better to suffer for well-doing, if the will of God, than for evil-doing".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:40
verses.text: But if one should captiously  say, And how is it possible for feeble flesh to resist the energies and spirits of the Powers? well, let him know this, that, confiding in the Almighty and the Lord, we war against the principalities of darkness, and against death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:41
verses.text: "Whilst thou art yet speaking," He says, "Lo, here am I".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:42
verses.text: See the invincible Helper who shields us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:43
verses.text: "Think it not strange, therefore, concerning the burning sent for your trial, as though some strange thing happened to you; But, as you are partaken in the sufferings of Christ, rejoice; that at the revelation of His glory ye may rejoice exultant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:44
verses.text: If ye be reproached in the name of Christ, happy are ye; for the Spirit of glory and of God resteth on you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:45
verses.text: As it is written, "Because for Thy sake we are killed all the day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:46
verses.text: Nay, in all these things we are more than conquerors, through Him that loved us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:47
verses.text: "What you wish to ascertain from my mind, You shall not ascertain, not were you to apply Horrid saws from the crown of my head to the soles of my feet, Not were you to load me with chains,"  says a woman acting manfully in the tragedy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:48
verses.text: And Antigone, contemning the proclamation of Creon, says boldly:—  "It was not Zeus who uttered this proclamation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:49
verses.text: But it is God that makes proclamation to us, and He must be believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:50
verses.text: "For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness; and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:51
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture saith, "Whosoever believeth on Him shall not be put to shame".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:52
verses.text: Accordingly Simonides justly writes, "It is said that virtue dwells among all but inaccessible rocks, but that she speedily traverses a pure place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:53
verses.text: Nor is she visible to the eyes of all mortals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:54
verses.text: He who is not penetrated by heart-vexing sweat will not scale the summit of manliness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:55
verses.text: And Pindar says:—  "But the anxious thoughts of youths, revolving with toils, Will find glory: and in time their deeds Will in resplendent ether splendid shine".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:56
verses.text: aeschylus, too, having grasped this thought, says:—  "To him who toils is due, As product of his toil, glory from the gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:57
verses.text: "For great Fates attain great destinies," according to Heraclitus:—  "And what slave is there, who is careless of death?"  "For God hath not given us the spirit of bondage again to fear; but of power, and love, and of a sound mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:58
verses.text: Be not therefore ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, or of me his prisoner," he writes to Timothy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:59
verses.text: Such shall he be "who cleaves to that which is good," according to the apostle, "who hates evil, having love unfeigned; for he that loveth another fulfilleth the law".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:60
verses.text: If, then, this God, to whom we bear witness, be as He is, the God of hope, we acknowledge our hope, speeding on to hope, "saturated with goodness, filled with all knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:61
verses.text: The Indian sages say to Alexander of Macedon: "You transport men's bodies from place to place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:62
verses.text: But you shall not force our souls to do what we do not wish.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:63
verses.text: Fire is to men the greatest torture, this we despise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:64
verses.text: Hence Heraclitus preferred one thing, glory, to all else; and professes "that he allows the crowd to stuff themselves to satiety like cattle".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:65
verses.text: "For on account of the body are many toils, For it we have invented a roofed house, And discovered how to dig up silver, and sow the land, And all the rest which we know by names".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:66
verses.text: To the multitude, then, this vain labour is desirable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:67
verses.text: But to us the apostle says, "Now we know this, that our old man is crucified with Him, that the body of sin might be destroyed, that henceforth we should not serve sin".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:68
verses.text: Does not the apostle then plainly add the following, to show the contempt for faith in the case of the multitude? "For I think that God hath set forth us the apostles last, as appointed to death: we are made a spectacle to the world, and to angels, and to men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:69
verses.text: Up to this present hour we both hunger, and thirst, and are naked, and are beaten, and are feeble, and labour, working with our hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:70
verses.text: Being reviled, we bless; being persecuted, we endure; being defamed, we entreat; we are become as it were the offscourings of the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:71
verses.text: Such also are the words of Plato in the Republic: "The just man, though stretched on the rack, though his eyes are dug out, will be happy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:72
verses.text: The Gnostic will never then have the chief end placed in life, but in being always happy and blessed, and a kingly friend of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:73
verses.text: Although visited with ignominy and exile, and confiscation, and above all, death, he will never be wrenched from his freedom, and signal love to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:74
verses.text: "The charity which bears all things, endures all things," is assured that Divine Providence orders all things well.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:75
verses.text: "I exhort you," therefore it is said, "Be followers of me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:76
verses.text: The first step to salvation is the instruction accompanied with fear, in consequence of which we abstain from what is wrong; and the second is  hope, by reason of which we desire the best things; but love, as is fitting, perfects, by training now according to knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:77
verses.text: For the Greeks, I know not how, attributing events to unreasoning necessity, own that they yield to them unwillingly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:78
verses.text: Accordingly Euripides says:—  "What I declare, receive from me, madam: No mortal exists who has not toil; He buries children, and begets others, And he himself dies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:79
verses.text: And thus mortals are afflicted".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:80
verses.text: Then he adds:—  "We must bear those things which are inevitable according to nature, and go through them: Not one of the things which are necessary is formidable for mortals".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:81
verses.text: And for those who are aiming at perfection there is proposed the rational gnosis, the foundation of which is "the sacred Triad".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:82
verses.text: "Faith, hope, love; but the greatest of these is love".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:83
verses.text: Truly, "all things are lawful, but all things are not expedient," says the apostle: "all things are lawful for me, but all things edify not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:84
verses.text: And, "Let no one seek his own advantage, but also that of his neighbour," so as to be able at once to do and to teach, building and building up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:85
verses.text: For that "the earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof," is admitted; but the conscience of the weak is supported.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:86
verses.text: "Conscience, I say, not his own, but that of the other; for why is my liberty judged of by another conscience? For if I by grace am partaker, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks? Whether therefore ye eat, or drink, or whatsoever ye do, do all to the glory of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:87
verses.text: "For though we walk in the flesh, we do not war after the flesh; for the weapons of our warfare are not carnal, but mighty through God to the demolition of fortifications, demolishing thoughts, and every high thing which exalteth itself against the knowledge of Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:88
verses.text: Equipped with these weapons, the Gnostic says: O Lord, give opportunity, and receive demonstration; let this dread event pass; I contemn dangers for the love I bear to Thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:89
verses.text: "Because alone of human things Virtue receives not a recompense from without, But has itself as the reward of its toils".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:90
verses.text: "Put on therefore, as the elect of God, holy and beloved, bowels of mercies, kindness, humbleness, meekness, long-suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:91
verses.text: And above all these, love, which is the bond of perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 7:92
verses.text: And let the peace of God reign in your hearts, to which also ye are called in one body; and be thankful," ye who, while still in the body, like the just men of old, enjoy impassibility and tranquillity of soul.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—Women as Well as Men, Slaves as Well as Freemen, Candidates for the Martyr's Crown.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:2
verses.text: Since, then, not only the aesopians, and Macedonians, and the Lacedaemonians endured when subjected to torture, as Eratosthenes says in his work, On Things Good and Evil; but also Zeno of Elea, when subjected to compulsion to divulge a secret, held out against the tortures, and confessed nothing; who, when expiring, bit out his tongue and spat it at the tyrant, whom some term Nearchus, and some Demulus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:3
verses.text: Theodotus the Pythagorean acted also similarly, and Paulus the friend of Lacydes, as Timotheus of Pergamus says in his work on The Fortitude of Philosophers, and Achaicus in The Ethics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:4
verses.text: Posthumus also, the Roman, when captured by Peucetion, did not divulge a single secret; but putting his hand on the fire, held it to it as if to a piece of brass, without moving a muscle of his face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:5
verses.text: I omit the case of Anaxarchus, who exclaimed, "Pound away at the sack which holds Anaxarchus, for it is not Anaxarchus you are pounding," when by the tyrant's orders he was being pounded with iron pestles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:6
verses.text: Neither, then, the hope of happiness nor the love of God takes what befalls ill, but remains free, although thrown among the wildest beasts or into the all-devouring fire; though racked with a tyrant's tortures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:7
verses.text: Depending as it does on the divine favour, it ascends aloft unenslaved, surrendering the body to those who can touch it alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:8
verses.text: A barbarous nation, not cumbered with philosophy, select, it is said, annually an ambassador to the hero Zamolxis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:9
verses.text: Zamolxis was one of the disciples of Pythagoras.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:10
verses.text: The one, then, who is judged of the most sterling worth is put to death, to the distress of those who have practiced philosophy, but have not been selected, at being reckoned unworthy of a happy service.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:11
verses.text: So the Church is full of those, as well chaste women as men, who all their life have contemplated the death which rouses up to Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:12
verses.text: For the individual whose life is framed as ours is, may philosophize without Learning, whether barbarian, whether Greek, whether slave—whether an old man, or a boy, or a woman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:13
verses.text: For self-control is common to all human beings who have made choice of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:14
verses.text: And we admit that the same nature exists in every race, and the same virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:15
verses.text: As far as respects human nature, the woman does not possess one nature, and the man exhibit another, but the same: so also with virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:16
verses.text: If, consequently, a self-restraint and righteousness, and whatever qualities are regarded as  following them, is the virtue of the male, it belongs to the male alone to be virtuous, and to the woman to be licentious and unjust.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:17
verses.text: But it is offensive even to say this.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:18
