verses.text: Accordingly woman is to practice self-restraint and righteousness, and every other virtue, as well as man, both bond and free; since it is a fit consequence that the same nature possesses one and the same virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:19
verses.text: We do not say that woman's nature is the same as man's, as she is woman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:20
verses.text: For undoubtedly it stands to reason that some difference should exist between each of them, in virtue of which one is male and the other female.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:21
verses.text: Pregnancy and parturition, accordingly, we say belong to woman, as she is woman, and not as she is a human being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:22
verses.text: But if there were no difference between man and woman, both would do and suffer the same things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:23
verses.text: As then there is sameness, as far as respects the soul, she will attain to the same virtue; but as there is difference as respects the peculiar construction of the body, she is destined for child-bearing and housekeeping.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:24
verses.text: "For I would have you know," says the apostle, "that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man: for the man is not of the woman, but the woman of the man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:25
verses.text: For neither is the woman without the man, nor the man without the woman, in the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:26
verses.text: For as we say that the man ought to be continent, and superior to pleasures; so also we reckon that the woman should be continent and practiced in fighting against pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:27
verses.text: "But I say, Walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lusts of the flesh," counsels the apostolic command; "for the flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:28
verses.text: These, then, are contrary" (not as good to evil, but as fighting advantageously), he adds therefore, so that ye cannot do the things that ye would.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:29
verses.text: Now the works of the flesh are manifest, which are, fornication uncleanness, profligacy, idolatry, witchcrafts, enmities, strifes, jealousies, wrath, contentions, dissensions, heresies, envyings, drunkenness, revellings, and such like; of which I tell you before, as I have also said before, that they which do such things shall not inherit the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:30
verses.text: But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, long-suffering, gentleness, temperance, goodness, faith, meekness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:31
verses.text: He calls sinners, as I think, "flesh," and the righteous "spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:32
verses.text: Further, manliness is to be assumed in order to produce confidence and forbearance, so as "to him that strikes on the one cheek, to give to him the other; and to him that takes away the cloak, to yield to him the coat also," strongly, restraining anger.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:33
verses.text: For we do not train our women like Amazons to manliness in war; since we wish the men even to be peaceable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:34
verses.text: I hear that the Sarmatian women practice war no less than the men; and the women of the Sacae besides, who shoot backwards, feigning flight as well as the men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:35
verses.text: I am aware, too, that the women near Iberia practice manly work and toil, not refraining from their tasks even though near their delivery; but even in the very struggle of her pains, the woman, on being delivered, taking up the infant, carries it home.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:36
verses.text: Further, the females no less than the males manage the house, and hunt, and keep the flocks:—  "Cressa the hound ran keenly in the stag's track".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:37
verses.text: Women are therefore to philosophize equally with men, though the males are preferable at everything, unless they have become effeminate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:38
verses.text: To the whole human race, then, discipline and virtue are a necessity, if they would pursue after happiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:39
verses.text: And how recklessly Euripides writes sometimes this and sometimes that! On one occasion, "For every wife is inferior to her husband, though the most excellent one marry her that is of fair fame".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:40
verses.text: And on another:—  "For the chaste is her husband's slave, While she that is unchaste in her folly despises her consort.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:41
verses.text: For nothing is better and more excellent, Than when as husband and wife ye keep house, Harmonious in your sentiments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:42
verses.text: The ruling power is therefore the head.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:43
verses.text: And if "the Lord is head of the man, and the man is head of the woman," the man, "being the image and glory of God, is lord of the woman".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:44
verses.text: Wherefore also in the Epistle to the Ephesians it is written, "Subjecting yourselves one to another in the fear of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:45
verses.text: Wives, submit yourselves to your own husbands, as to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:46
verses.text: For the husband is head of the wife, as also Christ is the head of the Church; and He is the Saviour of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:47
verses.text: Husbands, love your wives, as also Christ loved the Church.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:48
verses.text: So also ought men to love their wives as their own bodies: he that loveth his wife loveth himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:49
verses.text: For no man ever yet hated his own flesh".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:50
verses.text: And in that to the Colossians it is said, "Wives, submit yourselves to your own husbands, as is fit in the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:51
verses.text: Husbands, love your wives, and be not bitter against them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:52
verses.text: Children, obey your parents in all things; for this is well pleasing to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:53
verses.text: Fathers, provoke not your children to anger, lest they be discouraged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:54
verses.text: Servants, be obedient in all things to those who  are your masters according to the flesh; not with eye-service, as men-pleasers; but with singleness of heart, fearing the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:55
verses.text: And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as serving the Lord and not men; knowing that of the Lord ye shall receive the reward of the inheritance: for ye serve the Lord Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:56
verses.text: For the wrongdoer shall receive the wrong, which he hath done; and there is no respect of persons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:57
verses.text: Masters, render to your servants justice and equity; knowing that ye also have a Master in heaven, where there is neither Greek nor Jew, circumcision and uncircumcision, barbarian, Scythian, bond, free: but Christ is all, and in all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:58
verses.text: And the earthly Church is the image of the heavenly, as we pray also "that the will of God may be done upon the earth as in heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:59
verses.text: "Putting on, therefore, bowels of mercy, gentleness, humbleness, meekness, long-suffering; forbearing one another, and forgiving one another, if one have a quarrel against any man; as also Christ hath forgiven us, so also let us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:60
verses.text: And above all these things put on charity, which is the bond of perfectness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:61
verses.text: And let the peace of God rule in your hearts, to which ye are called in one body; and be thankful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:62
verses.text: For there is no obstacle to adducing frequently the same Scripture in order to put Marcion to the blush, if perchance he be persuaded and converted; by learning that the faithful ought to be grateful to God the Creator, who hath called us, and who preached the Gospel in the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:63
verses.text: From these considerations the unity of the faith is clear, and it is shown who is the perfect man; so that though some are reluctant, and offer as much resistance as they can, though menaced with punishments at the hand of husband or master, both the domestic and the wife will philosophize.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:64
verses.text: Moreover, the free, though threatened with death at a tyrant's hands, and brought before the tribunals, and all his substances imperilled, will by no means abandon piety; nor will the wife who dwells with a wicked husband, or the son if he has a bad father, or the domestic if he has a bad master, ever fail in holding nobly to virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:65
verses.text: But as it is noble for a man to die for virtue, and for liberty, and for himself, so also is it for a woman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:66
verses.text: For this is not peculiar to the nature of males, but to the nature of the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:67
verses.text: Accordingly, both the old man, the young, and the servant will live faithfully, and if need be die; which will be to be made alive by death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:68
verses.text: So we know that both children, and women, and servants have often, against their fathers', and masters', and husbands' will, reached the highest degree of excellence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:69
verses.text: Wherefore those who are determined to live piously ought none the less to exhibit alacrity, when some seem to exercise compulsion on them; but much more, I think, does it become them to show eagerness, and to strive with uncommon vigour, lest, being overcome, they abandon the best and most indispensable counsels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:70
verses.text: For it does not, I think, admit of comparison, whether it be better to be a follower of the Almighty than to choose the darkness of demons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:71
verses.text: For the things which are done by us on account of others we are to do always, endeavouring to have respect to those for whose sake it is proper that they be done, regarding the gratification rendered in their case, as what is to be our rule; but the things which are done for our own sake rather than that of others, are to be done with equal earnestness, whether they are like to please certain people or not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:72
verses.text: If some indifferent things have obtained such honour as to appear worthy of adoption, though against the will of some; much more is virtue to be regarded by us as worth contending for, looking the while to nothing but what can be rightly done, whether it seem good to others or not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:73
verses.text: Well then, Epicurus, writing to Menoeceus, says, "Let not him who is young delay philosophizing, and let not the old man grow weary of philosophizing; for no one is either not of age or past age for attending to the health of his soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:74
verses.text: And he who says that the time for philosophizing is not come or is past, is like the man who says that the time for happiness is not come or has gone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 8:75
verses.text: So that young as well as old ought to philosophize: the one, in order that, while growing old, he may grow young in good things out of favour accruing from what is past; and the other, that he may be at once young and old, from want of fear for the future".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Christ's Sayings Respecting Martyrdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:2
verses.text: On martyrdom the Lord hath spoken explicitly, and what is written in different places we bring together.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:3
verses.text: "But I say unto you, Whosoever shall confess in Me before men, the Son of man also shall confess before the angels of God; but whosoever shall deny Me before men, him will I deny before the angels".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:4
verses.text: "Whosoever shall be ashamed of Me or of My words in this adulterous and sinful generation, of him shall the Son of man also be ashamed when He cometh in the glory of His Father with His angels.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:5
verses.text: Whosoever therefore shall confess in Me before men, him will I also confess before my Father in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:6
verses.text: "And when they bring you before synagogues, and rulers, and powers, think not beforehand how ye shall make your defence, or what ye shall say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:7
verses.text: For the Holy Spirit shall teach you in the same hour what ye must say".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:8
verses.text: In explanation of this passage, Heracleon, the most distinguished of the school of Valentinians, says expressly, "that there is a confession by faith and conduct, and one with the voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:9
verses.text: The confession that is made with the voice, and before the authorities, is what the most reckon the only confession.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:10
verses.text: Not soundly: and hypocrites also can confess with this confession.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:11
verses.text: But neither will this utterance be found to be spoken universally; for all the saved have confessed with the confession made by the voice, and departed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:12
verses.text: Of whom are Matthew, Philip, Thomas, Levi, and many others.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:13
verses.text: And confession by the lip is not universal, but partial.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:14
verses.text: But that which He specifies now is universal, that which is by deeds and actions corresponding to faith in Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:15
verses.text: This confession is followed by that which is partial, that before the authorities, if necessary, and reason dictate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:16
verses.text: For he will confess rightly with his voice who has first confessed by his disposition.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:17
verses.text: And he has well used, with regard to those who confess, the expression 'in Me,' and applied to those who deny the expression'Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:18
verses.text: ' For those, though they confess Him with the voice, yet deny Him, not confessing Him in their conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:19
verses.text: But those alone confess 'in Him,' who live in the confession and conduct according to Him, in which He also confesses, who is contained in them and held by them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:20
verses.text: Wherefore 'He never can deny Himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:21
verses.text: ' And those deny Him who are not in Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:22
verses.text: For He said not, 'Whosoever shall deny' in Me, but 'Me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:23
verses.text: ' For no one who is in Him will ever deny Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:24
verses.text: And the expression 'before men' applies both to the saved and the heathen similarly by conduct before the one, and by voice before the other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:25
verses.text: Wherefore they never can deny Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:26
verses.text: But those deny Him who are not in Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:27
verses.text: So far Heracleon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:28
verses.text: And in other things he seems to be of the same sentiments with us in this section; but he has not adverted to this, that if some have not by conduct and in their life "confessed Christ before men," they are manifested to have believed with the heart; by confessing Him with the mouth at the tribunals, and not denying Him when tortured to the death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:29
verses.text: And the disposition being confessed, and especially not being changed by death at any time, cuts away all passions which were engendered by corporeal desire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:30
verses.text: For there is, so to speak, at the close of life a sudden repentance in action, and a true confession toward Christ, in the testimony of the voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:31
verses.text: But if the Spirit of the Father testifies in us, how can we be any more hypocrites, who are said to bear testimony with the voice alone? But it will be given to some, if expedient, to make a defence, that by their witness and confession all may be benefited—those in the Church being confirmed, and those of the heathen who have devoted themselves to the search after salvation wondering and being led to the faith; and the rest seized with amazement.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:32
verses.text: So that confession is by all means necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:33
verses.text: For it is in our power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:34
verses.text: But to make a defence for our faith is not universally necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:35
verses.text: For that does not depend on us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:36
verses.text: "But he that endureth to the end shall be saved".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:37
verses.text: For who of those who are wise would not choose to reign in God, and even to serve? So some "confess that they know God," according to the apostle; "but in works they deny Him, being abominable and disobedient, and to every good work reprobate".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:38
verses.text: And these, though they confess nothing but this, will have done at the end one good work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:39
verses.text: Their witness, then, appears to be the cleansing away of sins with glory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:40
verses.text: For instance, the Shepherd says: "You will escape the energy of the wild beast, if your heart become pure and blameless".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:41
verses.text: Also the Lord Himself says: "Satan hath desired to sift you; but I have prayed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:42
verses.text: Alone, therefore, the Lord, for the purification of the men who plotted against Him and disbelieved Him, "drank the cup;" in imitation of whom the apostles, that they might be in reality Gnostics, and perfect, suffered for the Churches which they founded.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:43
verses.text: So, then, also the Gnostics who tread in the footsteps of the apostles ought to be sinless, and, out of love to the Lord, to love also their brother; so that, if occasion call, enduring without stumbling, afflictions for the Church, "they may drink the cup".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:44
verses.text: Those who witness in their life by deed, and at the tribunal by word, whether entertaining hope or surmising fear, are better than those who confess salvation by their mouth alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 9:45
verses.text: But if one ascend also to love, he is a really blessed and true martyr, having confessed perfectly both to the commandments and to God, by the Lord; whom having loved, he acknowledged a brother, giving himself up wholly for God, resigning pleasantly and lovingly the man when asked, like a deposit.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—Those Who Offered Themselves for Martyrdom Reproved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:2
verses.text: When, again, He says, "When they persecute you in this city, flee ye to the other," He does not advise flight, as if persecution were an evil thing; nor does He enjoin them by flight to avoid death, as if in dread of it, but wishes us neither to be the authors nor abettors of any evil to any one, either to ourselves or the persecutor and murderer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:3
verses.text: For He, in a way, bids us take care of ourselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:4
verses.text: But he who disobeys is rash and foolhardy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:5
verses.text: If he who kills a man of God sins against God, he also who presents himself before the judgment-seat becomes guilty of his death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:6
verses.text: And such is also the case with him who does not avoid persecution, but out of daring presents himself for capture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:7
verses.text: Such a one, as far as in him lies, becomes an accomplice in the crime of the persecutor.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:8
verses.text: And if he also uses provocation, he is wholly guilty, challenging the wild beast.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:9
verses.text: And similarly, if he afford any cause for conflict or punishment, or retribution or enmity, he gives occasion for persecution.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 10:10
verses.text: Wherefore, then, we are enjoined not to cling to anything that belongs to this life; but "to him that takes our cloak to give our coat," not only that we may continue destitute of inordinate affection, but that we may not by retaliating make our persecutors savage against ourselves, and stir them up to blaspheme the name.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—The Objection, Why Do You Suffer If God Cares for You, Answered.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:2
verses.text: But, say they, if God cares for you, why are you persecuted and put to death? Has He delivered you to this? No, we do not suppose that the Lord wishes us to be involved in calamities, but that He foretold prophetically what would happen—that we should be persecuted for His name's sake, slaughtered, and impaled.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:3
verses.text: So that it was not that He wished us to be persecuted, but He intimated beforehand what we shall suffer by the prediction of what would take place, training us to endurance, to which He promised the inheritance, although we are punished not alone, but along with many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:4
verses.text: But those, it is said, being malefactors, are righteously punished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:5
verses.text: Accordingly, they unwillingly bear testimony to our righteousness, we being unjustly punished for righteousness' sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:6
verses.text: But the injustice of the judge does not affect the providence of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:7
verses.text: For the judge must be master of his own opinion—not pulled by strings, like inanimate machines, set in motion only by external causes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:8
verses.text: Accordingly he is judged in respect to his judgment, as we also, in accordance with our choice of things desirable, and our endurance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:9
verses.text: Although we do not wrong, yet the judge looks on us as doing wrong, for he neither knows nor wishes to know about us, but is influenced by unwarranted prejudice; wherefore also he is judged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:10
verses.text: Accordingly they persecute us, not from the supposition that we are wrong-doers, but imagining that by the very fact of our being Christians we sin against life in so conducting ourselves, and exhorting others to adopt the like life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:11
verses.text: But why are you not helped when persecuted? say they.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:12
verses.text: What wrong is done us, as far as we are concerned, in being released by death to go to the Lord, and so undergoing a change of life, as if a change from one time of life to another? Did we think rightly, we should feel obliged to those who have afforded the means for speedy departure, if it is for love that we bear witness; and if not, we should appear to the multitude to be base men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:13
verses.text: Had they also known the truth, all would have bounded on to the way, and there would have been no choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:14
verses.text: But our faith, being the light of the world, reproves unbelief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:15
verses.text: "Should Anytus and Melitus kill me, they will not hurt me in the least; for I do not think it right for the better to be hurt by the worse," says Socrates.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 11:16
verses.text: So that each one of us may with confidence say, "The Lord is my helper; I will not fear: what shall man do to me?" "For the souls of the righteous are in the hand of the Lord, and no plague shall touch them".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—Basilides' Idea of Martyrdom Refuted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:2
verses.text: Basilides, in the twenty-third book of the Exegetics, respecting those that are punished by martyrdom, expresses himself in the following language: "For I say this, Whosoever fall under the afflictions mentioned, in consequence of unconsciously transgressing in other matters, are brought to this good end by the kindness of Him who brings them, but accused on other grounds; so that they may not suffer as condemned for what are owned to be iniquities, nor reproached as the adulterer or the murderer, but because they are Christians; which will console them, so that they do not appear to suffer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:3
verses.text: And if one who has not sinned at all incur suffering—a rare case—yet even he will not suffer aught through the machinations of power, but will suffer as the child which seems not to have sinned would suffer".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:4
verses.text: Then further on he adds: "As, then, the child which has not sinned before, or committed actual sin in itself, but has that which committed sin, when subjected to  suffering, gets good, reaping the advantage of many difficulties; so also, although a perfect man may not have sinned in act, while he endures afflictions, he suffers similarly with the child.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:5
verses.text: Having within him the sinful principle, but not embracing the opportunity of committing sin, he does not sin; so that he is not to be reckoned as not having sinned.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:6
verses.text: For as he who wishes to commit adultery is an adulterer, although he does not succeed in committing adultery; and he that wishes to commit murder is a murderer, although he is unable to kill; so also, if I see the man without sin, whom I specify, suffering, though he have done nothing bad, I should call him bad, on account of his wishing to sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:7
verses.text: For I will affirm anything rather than call Providence evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:8
verses.text: Then, in continuation, he says expressly concerning the Lord, as concerning man: "If then, passing from all these observations, you were to proceed to put me to shame by saying, perchance impersonating certain parties, This man has then sinned; for this man has suffered;—if you permit, I will say, He has not sinned; but was like a child suffering.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:9
verses.text: If you were to insist more urgently, I would say, That the man you name is man, but that God is righteous: "For no one is pure," as one said, 'from pollution.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:10
verses.text: '" But the hypothesis of Basilides says that the soul, having sinned before in another life, endures punishment in this—the elect soul with honour by martyrdom, the other purged by appropriate punishment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:11
verses.text: How can this be true, when the confessing and suffering punishment or not depends on ourselves? For in the case of the man who shall deny, Providence, as held by Basilides, is done away with.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:12
verses.text: I will ask him, then, in the case of a confessor who has been arrested, whether he will confess and be punished in virtue of Providence or not? For in the case of denying he will not be punished.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:13
verses.text: But if, for the sake of escaping and evading the necessity of punishing such an one, he shall say that the destruction of those who shall deny is of Providence, he will be a martyr against his will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:14
verses.text: And how any more is it the case, that there is laid up in heaven the very glorious recompense to him who has witnessed, for his witnessing? If Providence did not permit the sinner to get the length of sinning, it is unjust in both cases; both in not rescuing the man who is dragged to punishment for righteousness' sake, and in having rescued him who wished to do wrong, he having done it as far as volition was concerned, but Providence having prevented the deed, and unjustly favoured the sinner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:15
verses.text: And how impious, in deifying the devil, and in daring to call the Lord a sinful man! For the devil tempting us, knowing what we are, but not knowing if we will hold out, but wishing to dislodge us from the faith, attempts also to bring us into subjection to himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:16
verses.text: Which is all that is allowed to him, partly from the necessity of saving us, who have taken occasion from the commandment, from ourselves; partly for the confusion of him who has tempted and failed; for the confirmation of the members of the Church, and the conscience of those who admire the constancy displayed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:17
verses.text: But if martyrdom be retribution by way of punishment, then also faith and doctrine, on account of which martyrdom comes, are co-operators in punishment—than which, what other absurdity could be greater? But with reference to these dogmas, whether the soul is changed to another body, also of the devil, at the proper time mention will be made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:18
verses.text: But at present, to what has been already said, let us add the following: Where any more is faith in the retribution of sins committed before martyrdom takes place? And where is love to God, which is persecuted and endures for the truth? And where is the praise of him who has confessed, or the censure of him who has denied? And for what use is right conduct, the mortification of the lusts, and the hating of no creature? But if, as Basilides himself says, we suppose one part of the declared will of God to be the loving of all things because all things bear a relation to the whole, and another "not to lust after anything," and a third "not to hate anything," by the will of God these also will be punishments, which it were impious to think.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:19
verses.text: For neither did the Lord suffer by the will of the Father, nor are those who are persecuted persecuted by the will of God; since either of two things is the case: either persecution in consequence of the will of God is a good thing, or those who decree and afflict are guiltless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:20
verses.text: But nothing is without the will of the Lord of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:21
verses.text: It remains to say that such things happen without the prevention of God; for this alone saves both the providence and the goodness of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:22
verses.text: We must not therefore think that He actively produces afflictions (far be it that we should think this!); but we must be persuaded that He does not prevent those that cause them, but overrules for good the crimes of His enemies: "I will therefore," He says, "destroy the wall, and it shall be for treading under foot".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:23
verses.text: Providence being a disciplinary art; in the case of others for each individual's sins, and in the case of the Lord and His apostles for ours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:24
verses.text: To this  point says the divine apostle: "For this is the will of God, even your sanctification, that ye abstain from fornication: that each one of you should know how to possess his vessel in sanctification and honour; not in the lust of concupiscence, as the Gentiles who know not the Lord: that none of you should overreach or take advantage of his brother in any matter; because the Lord is the avenger in respect of all such, as we also told you before, and testified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:25
verses.text: For God hath not called us unto uncleanness, but to holiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:26
verses.text: Wherefore he that despiseth, despiseth not man, but God, who hath also given His Holy Spirit to you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:27
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord was not prohibited from this sanctification of ours.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:28
verses.text: If, then, one of them were to say, in reply, that the martyr is punished for sins committed before this embodying, and that he will again reap the fruit of his conduct in this life, for that such are the arrangements of the divine administration, we shall ask him if the retribution takes place by Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:29
verses.text: For if it be not of the divine administration, the economy of expiations is gone, and their hypothesis falls to the ground; but if expiations are by Providence, punishments are by Providence too.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:30
verses.text: But Providence, although it begins, so to speak, to move with the Ruler, yet is implanted in substances along with their origin by the God of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:31
verses.text: Such being the case, they must confess either that punishment is not just, and those who condemn and persecute the martyrs do right, or that persecutions even are wrought by the will of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:32
verses.text: Labour and fear are not, then, as they say, incident to affairs as rust to iron, but come upon the soul through its own will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 12:33
verses.text: And on these points there is much to say, which will be reserved for future consideration, taking them up in due course.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—Valentinian's Vagaries About the Abolition of Death Refuted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:2
verses.text: Valentinian, in a homily, writes in these words: "Ye are originally immortal, and children of eternal life, and ye would have death distributed to you, that ye may spend and lavish it, and that death may die in you and by you; for when we dissolve the world, and are not yourselves dissolved, ye have dominion over creation and all corruption".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:3
verses.text: For he also, similarly with Basilides, supposes a class saved by nature, and that this different race has come hither to us from above for the abolition of death, and that the origin of death is the work of the Creator of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:4
verses.text: Wherefore also he so expounds that Scripture, "No man shall see the face of God, and live," as if He were the cause of death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:5
verses.text: Respecting this God, he makes those allusions when writing in these expressions: "As much as the image is inferior to the living face, so much is the world inferior to the living aeon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:6
verses.text: What is, then, the cause of the image? The majesty of the face, which exhibits the figure to the painter, to be honoured by his name; for the form is not found exactly to the life, but the name supplies what is wanting in the effigy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:7
verses.text: The invisibility of God co-operates also in order to the faith of that which has been fashioned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:8
verses.text: For the Creator, called God and Father, he designated as "Painter," and "Wisdom," whose image that which is formed is, to the glory of the invisible One; since the things which proceed from a pair are complements, and those which proceed from one are images.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:9
verses.text: But since what is seen is no part of Him, the soul comes from what is intermediate, which is different; and this is the inspiration of the different spirit, and generally what is breathed into the soul, which is the image of the spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:10
verses.text: And in general, what is said of the Creator, who was made according to the image, they say was foretold by a sensible image in the book of Genesis respecting the origin of man; and the likeness they transfer to themselves, teaching that the addition of the different spirit was made; unknown to the Creator.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:11
verses.text: When, then, we treat of the unity of the God who is proclaimed in the law, the prophets, and the Gospel, we shall also discuss this; for the topic is supreme.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:12
verses.text: But we must advance to that which is urgent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:13
verses.text: If for the purpose of doing away with death the peculiar race has come, it is not Christ who has abolished death, unless He also is said to be of the same essence with them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:14
verses.text: And if He abolished it to this end, that it might not touch the peculiar race, it is not these, the rivals of the Creator, who breathe into the image of their intermediate spirit the life from above—in accordance with the principle of their dogma—that abolish death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:15
verses.text: But should they say that this takes place by His mother, or should they say that they, along with Christ, war against death, let them own their secret dogma that they have the hardihood to assail the divine power of the Creator, by setting to rights His creation, as if they were superior, endeavouring to save the vital image which He was not able to rescue from corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:16
verses.text: Then the Lord would be superior to God the Creator; for the son would never contend with the father, especially among the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:17
verses.text: But the point that the Creator of all things, the omnipotent Lord, is the Father of the Son, we have deferred till the discussion of these points, in which we have undertaken  to dispute against the heresies, showing that He alone is the God proclaimed by Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:18
verses.text: But the apostle, writing to us with reference to the endurance of afflictions, says, "And this is of God, that it is given to you on behalf of Christ, not only to believe on Him, but also to suffer for His sake; having the same conflict which ye saw in me, and now hear to be in me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:19
verses.text: If there is therefore any consolation in Christ, if any comfort of love, if any communion of spirit, if any bowels and mercies, fulfil ye my joy, that ye may be of the same mind, having the same love, unanimous, thinking one thing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:20
verses.text: And if he is offered on the sacrifice and service of faith, joying and rejoicing" with the Philippians, to whom the apostle speaks, calling them "fellow-partakers of joy," how does he say that they are of one soul, and having a soul? Likewise, also, writing respecting Timothy and himself, he says, "For I have no one like-souled, who will nobly care for your state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:21
verses.text: For all seek their own, not the things which are Jesus Christ's".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:22
verses.text: Let not the above-mentioned people, then, call us, by way of reproach, "natural men" (ψυκικοί), nor the Phrygians either; for these now call those who do not apply themselves to the new prophecy "natural men" (ψυκικοί), with whom we shall discuss in our remarks on "Prophecy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:23
verses.text: The perfect man ought therefore to practice love, and thence to haste to the divine friendship, fulfilling the commandments from love.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:24
verses.text: And loving one's enemies does not mean loving wickedness, or impiety, or adultery, or theft; but the thief, the impious, the adulterer, not as far as he sins, and in respect of the actions by which he stains the name of man, but as he is a man, and the work of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:25
verses.text: Assuredly sin is an activity, not an existence: and therefore it is not a work of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:26
verses.text: Now sinners are called enemies of God—enemies, that is, of the commands which they do not obey, as those who obey become friends, the one named so from their fellowship, the others from their estrangement, which is the result of free choice; for there is neither enmity nor sin without the enemy and the sinner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:27
verses.text: And the command "to covet nothing," not as if the things to be desired did not belong to us, does not teach us not to entertain desire, as those suppose who teach that the Creator is different from the first God, not as if creation was loathsome and bad (for such opinions are impious).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:28
verses.text: But we say that the things of the world are not our own, not as if they were monstrous, not as if they did not belong to God, the Lord of the universe, but because we do not continue among them for ever; being, in respect of possession, not ours, and passing from one to another in succession; but belonging to us, for whom they were made in respect of use, so long as it is necessary to continue with them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 13:29
verses.text: In accordance, therefore, with natural appetite, things disallowed are to be used rightly, avoiding all excess and inordinate affection.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—The Love of All, Even of Our Enemies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:2
verses.text: How great also is benignity! "Love your enemies," it is said, "bless them who curse you, and pray for them who despitefully use you," and the like; to which it is added, "that ye may be the children of your Father who is in heaven," in allusion to resemblance to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:3
verses.text: Again, it is said, "Agree with thine adversary quickly, whilst thou art in the way with him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:4
verses.text: The adversary is not the body, as some would have it, but the devil, and those assimilated to him, who walks along with us in the person of men, who emulate his deeds in this earthly life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:5
verses.text: It is inevitable, then, that those who confess themselves to belong to Christ, but find themselves in the midst of the devil's works, suffer the most hostile treatment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:6
verses.text: For it is written, "Lest he deliver thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officers of Satan's kingdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:7
verses.text: "For I am persuaded that neither death," through the assault of persecutors, "nor life" in this world, "nor angels," the apostate ones, "nor powers" (and Satan's power is the life which he chose, for such are the powers and principalities of darkness belonging to him), "nor things present," amid which we exist during the time of life, as the hope entertained by the soldier, and the merchant's gain, "nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature," in consequence of the energy proper to a man,—opposes the faith of him who acts according to free choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:8
verses.text: "Creature" is synonymous with activity, being our work, and such activity "shall not be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 14:9
verses.text: You have got a compendious account of the gnostic martyr.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—On Avoiding Offence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:2
verses.text: "We know that we all have knowledge"—common knowledge in common things, and the knowledge that there is one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:3
verses.text: For he was writing to believers; whence he adds, "But knowledge (gnosis) is not in all," being communicated to few.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:4
verses.text: And there are those who say that the knowledge about things sacrificed to idols is not promulgated among all, "lest our liberty prove a stumbling-block to the weak.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:5
verses.text: For by thy knowledge he that is weak is destroyed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:6
verses.text: Should they say, "Whatsoever is sold in the shambles, ought that to be bought?" adding, by way of interrogation, "asking no questions," as if equivalent to "asking questions," they give a ridiculous interpretation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:7
verses.text: For the apostle says, "All other things buy out of the shambles, asking no questions," with the exception of the things mentioned in the Catholic epistle of all the apostles, "with the consent of the Holy Ghost," which is written in the Acts of the Apostles, and conveyed to the faithful by the hands of Paul himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:8
verses.text: For they intimated "that they must of necessity abstain from things offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from fornication, from which keeping themselves, they should do well".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:9
verses.text: It is a different matter, then, which is expressed by the apostle: "Have we not power to eat and to drink? Have we not power to lead about a sister, a wife, as the rest of the apostles, as the brethren of the Lord and Cephas? But we have not used this power," he says, "but bear all things, lest we should occasion hindrance to the Gospel of Christ;" namely, by bearing about burdens, when it was necessary to be untrammelled for all things; or to become an example to those who wish to exercise temperance, not encouraging each other to eat greedily of what is set before us, and not to consort inconsiderately with woman.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:10
verses.text: And especially is it incumbent on those entrusted with such a dispensation to exhibit to disciples a pure example.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:11
verses.text: "For though I be free from all men, I have made myself servant to all," it is said, "that I might gain all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:12
verses.text: And every one that striveth for mastery is temperate in all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:13
verses.text: "But the earth is the Lord's, and the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:14
verses.text: For conscience' sake, then, we are to abstain from what we ought to abstain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:15
verses.text: "Conscience, I say, not his own," for it is endued with knowledge, "but that of the other," lest he be trained badly, and by imitating in ignorance what he knows not, he become a despiser instead of a strong-minded man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 15:16
verses.text: "For why is my liberty judged of by another conscience? For if I by grace am a partaker, why am I evil spoken of for that for which I give thanks? Whatever ye do, do all to the glory of God"—what you are commanded to do by the rule of faith.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Passages of Scripture Respecting the Constancy, Patience, and Love of the Martyrs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:2
verses.text: "With the heart man believeth unto righteousness, and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:3
verses.text: Wherefore the Scripture saith, Whosoever believeth on Him shall not be ashamed; that is, the word of faith which we preach: for if thou confess the word with thy mouth that Jesus is Lord, and believe in thy heart that God hath raised Him from the dead, thou shalt be saved".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:4
verses.text: There is clearly described the perfect righteousness, fulfilled both in practice and contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:5
verses.text: Wherefore we are "to bless those who persecute us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:6
verses.text: Bless, and curse not".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:7
verses.text: "For our rejoicing is this, the testimony of a good conscience, that in holiness and sincerity we know God" by this inconsiderable instance exhibiting the work of love, that "not in fleshly wisdom, but by the grace of God, we have had our conversation in the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:8
verses.text: So far the apostle respecting knowledge; and in the second Epistle to the Corinthians he calls the common "teaching of faith" the savour of knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:9
verses.text: "For unto this day the same veil remains on many in the reading of the Old Testament," not being uncovered by turning to the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:10
verses.text: Wherefore also to those capable of perceiving he showed resurrection, that of the life still in the flesh, creeping on its belly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:11
verses.text: Whence also he applied the name "brood of vipers" to the voluptuous, who serve the belly and the pudenda, and cut off one another's heads for the sake of worldly pleasures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:12
verses.text: "Little children, let us not love in word, or in tongue," says John, teaching them to be perfect, "but in deed and in truth; hereby shall we know that we are of the truth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:13
verses.text: And if "God be love," piety also is love: "there is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:14
verses.text: "This is the love of God, that we keep His commandments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:15
verses.text: And again, to him who desires to become a Gnostic, it is written, "But be thou an example of the believers, in word, in conversation, in love, in faith, in purity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:16
verses.text: For perfection in faith differs, I think, from ordinary faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:17
verses.text: And the divine apostle furnishes the rule for the Gnostic in these words, writing as follows: "For I have learned, in whatsoever state I am, to be content.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:18
verses.text: I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:19
verses.text: Everywhere and in all things I am instructed both to be full and to be hungry, both to abound and to lack.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:20
verses.text: I can do all things through Him who strengtheneth me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:21
verses.text: And also when discussing with others in order to put them, to shame, he does not shrink from saying, "But call to mind the former days, in which, after ye were illuminated, ye endured a great fight of  afflictions; partly, whilst ye were made a gazing-stock, both by reproaches and afflictions; and partly, whilst ye became companions of them that were so used.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:22
verses.text: For ye had compassion of me in my bonds, and took with joy the spoiling of your goods, knowing that you have a better and enduring substance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:23
verses.text: Cast not away therefore your confidence, which hath great recompense of reward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:24
verses.text: For ye have need of patience, that, after doing the will of God, ye may obtain the promise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:25
verses.text: For yet a little while, and He that cometh will come, and will not tarry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:26
verses.text: Now the just shall live by faith: and if any man draw back, my soul shall have no pleasure in him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:27
verses.text: But we are not of them that draw back unto perdition, but of them that believe to the saving of the soul".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:28
verses.text: He then brings forward a swarm of divine examples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:29
verses.text: For was it not "by faith," he says, this endurance, that they acted nobly who "had trial of mockeries and scourgings, and, moreover, of bonds and imprisonments? They were stoned, they were tempted, were slain with the sword.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:30
verses.text: They wandered about in sheep-skins and goat-skins, being destitute, afflicted, tormented, of whom the world was not worthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:31
verses.text: They wandered in deserts, in mountains, in dens, and caves of the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:32
verses.text: And all having received a good report, through faith, received not the promise of God" (what is expressed by a parasiopesis is left to be understood, viz.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:33
verses.text: , "alone").

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:34
verses.text: He adds accordingly, "God having provided some better thing for us (for He was good), that they should not without us be made perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:35
verses.text: Wherefore also, having encompassing us such a cloud," holy and transparent, "of witnesses, laying aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, let us run with patience the race set before us, looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:36
verses.text: Since, then, he specifies one salvation in Christ of the righteous, and of us he has expressed the former unambiguously, and saying nothing less respecting Moses, adds, "Esteeming the reproach of Christ greater riches than the treasures of Egypt: for he had respect to the recompense of the reward.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:37
verses.text: By faith he forsook Egypt, not fearing the wrath of the king: for he endured as seeing Him who is invisible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:38
verses.text: The divine Wisdom says of the martyrs, "They seemed in the eyes of the foolish to die, and their departure was reckoned a calamity, and their migration from us an affliction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:39
verses.text: But they are in peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:40
verses.text: For though in the sight of men they were punished, their hope was full of immortality".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:41
verses.text: He then adds, teaching martyrdom to be a glorious purification, "And being chastened a little, they shall be benefited much; because God proved them," that is, suffered them to be tried, to put them to the proof, and to put to shame the author of their trial, "and found them worthy of Himself," plainly to be called sons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:42
verses.text: "As gold in the furnace He proved them, and as a whole burned-offering of sacrifice He accepted them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:43
verses.text: And in the time of their visitation they will shine forth, even as sparks run along the stubble.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 16:44
verses.text: They shall judge the nations, and rule over the peoples, and the Lord shall reign over them forever".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—Passages from Clement's Epistle to the Corinthians on Martyrdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:2
verses.text: Moreover, in the Epistle to the Corinthians, the Apostle Clement also, drawing a picture of the Gnostic, says: "For who that has sojourned among you has not proved your perfect and firm faith? and has not admired your sound and gentle piety? and has not celebrated the munificent style of your hospitality? and has not felicitated your complete and sure knowledge? For ye did all things impartially, and walked in the ordinances of God;" and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:3
verses.text: Then more clearly: "Let us fix our eyes on those who have yielded perfect service to His magnificent glory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:4
verses.text: Let us take Enoch, who, being by his obedience found righteous, was translated; and Noah, who, having believed, was saved; and Abraham, who for his faith and hospitality was called the friend of God, and was the father of Isaac".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:5
verses.text: "For hospitality and piety, Lot was saved from Sodom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:6
verses.text: "For faith and hospitality, Rahab the harlot was saved".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:7
verses.text: "From patience and faith they walked about in goat-skins, and sheep-skins, and folds of camels' hair, proclaiming the kingdom of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:8
verses.text: We name His prophets Elias, and Eliseus, and Ezekiel, and John".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:9
verses.text: "For Abraham, who for his free faith was called 'the friend of God,' was not elated by glory, but modestly said, 'I am dust and ashes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:10
verses.text: ' And of Job it is thus written: 'Job was just and blameless, true and pious, abstaining from all evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:11
verses.text: '" He it was who overcame the tempter by patience, and at once testified and was testified to by God; who keeps hold of humility, and says, "No one is pure from defilement, not even if his life were but for one day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:12
verses.text: "Moses, 'the servant who was faithful in all his house,' said to Him who uttered the oracles from the bush, 'Who am I, that Thou sendest me? I am slow of speech, and of a stammering tongue,' to minister the voice of God in human speech.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:13
verses.text: And again: 'I am smoke from a pot.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:14
verses.text: '" "For  God resisteth the proud, but giveth grace to the humble".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:15
verses.text: "David too, of whom the Lord, testifying, says, 'I found a man after my own heart, David the son of Jesse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:16
verses.text: With my holy oil I anointed him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:17
verses.text: ' But he also says to God, 'Pity me, O God, according to Thy mercy; and according to the multitude of Thy tender mercies, blot out my transgression.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:18
verses.text: Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:19
verses.text: For I know my transgression, and my sin is ever before me.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:20
verses.text: '" Then, alluding to sin which is not subject to the law, in the exercise of the moderation of true knowledge, he adds, "Against Thee only have I sinned, and done evil in Thy sight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:21
verses.text: For the Scripture somewhere says, "The Spirit of the Lord is a lamp, searching the recesses of the belly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:22
verses.text: And the more of a Gnostic a man becomes by doing right, the nearer is the illuminating Spirit to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:23
verses.text: "Thus the Lord draws near to the righteous, and none of the thoughts and reasonings of which we are the authors escape Him—I mean the Lord Jesus," the scrutinizer by His omnipotent will of our heart, "whose blood was consecrated for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:24
verses.text: Let us therefore respect those who are over us, and reverence the elders; let us honour the young, and let us teach the discipline of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:25
verses.text: For blessed is he who shall do and teach the Lord's commands worthily; and he is of a magnanimous mind, and of a mind contemplative of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:26
verses.text: "Let us direct our wives to what is good; let them exhibit," says he, "the lovable disposition of chastity; let them show the guileless will of their meekness; let them manifest the gentleness of their tongue by silence; let them give their love not according to their inclinations, but equal love in sanctity to all that fear God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:27
verses.text: Let our children share in the discipline that is in Christ; let them learn what humility avails before God; what is the power of holy love before God, how lovely and great is the fear of the Lord, saving all that walk in it holily; with a pure heart: for He is the Searcher of the thoughts and sentiments, whose breath is in us, and when He wills He will take it away".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:28
verses.text: "Now all those things are confirmed by the faith that is in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:29
verses.text: 'Come, ye children,' says the Lord, 'hearken to me, and I will teach you the fear of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:30
verses.text: Who is the man that desireth life, that loveth to see good days? ' Then He subjoins the gnostic mystery of the numbers seven and eight.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:31
verses.text: 'Stop thy tongue from evil, and thy lips from speaking guile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:32
verses.text: Depart from evil, and do good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:33
verses.text: Seek peace, and pursue it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:34
verses.text: ' For in these words He alludes to knowledge (gnosis), with abstinence from evil and the doing of what is good, teaching that it is to be perfected by word and deed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:35
verses.text: 'The eyes of the Lord are on the righteous, and His ears are to their prayer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:36
verses.text: But the face of God is against those that do evil, to root out their memory from the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:37
verses.text: The righteous cried, and the Lord heard, and delivered him out of all his distresses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:38
verses.text: ' 'Many are the stripes of sinners; but those who hope in the Lord, mercy shall compass about.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:39
verses.text: '" "A multitude of mercy," he nobly says, "surrounds him that trusts in the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:40
verses.text: For it is written in the Epistle to the Corinthians, "Through Jesus Christ our foolish and darkened mind springs up to the light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:41
verses.text: By Him the Sovereign Lord wished us to taste the knowledge that is immortal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:42
verses.text: And, showing more expressly the peculiar nature of knowledge, he added: "These things, then, being clear to us, looking into the depths of divine knowledge, we ought to do all things in order which the Sovereign Lord commanded us to perform at the appointed seasons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:43
verses.text: Let the wise man, then, show his wisdom not in words only, but in good deeds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:44
verses.text: Let the humble not testify to himself, but allow testimony to be borne to him by another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:45
verses.text: Let not him who is pure in the flesh boast, knowing that it is another who furnishes him with continence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 17:46
verses.text: Ye see, brethren, that the more we are subjected to peril, the more knowledge are we counted worthy of".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—On Love, and the Repressing of Our Desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:2
verses.text: "The decorous tendency of our philanthropy, therefore," according to Clement, "seeks the common good;" whether by suffering martyrdom, or by teaching by deed and word,—the latter being twofold, unwritten and written.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:3
verses.text: This is love, to love God and our neighbour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:4
verses.text: "This conducts to the height which is unutterable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:5
verses.text: 'Love covers a multitude of sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:6
verses.text: Love beareth all things, suffereth all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:7
verses.text: ' Love joins us to God, does all things in concord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:8
verses.text: In love, all the chosen of God were perfected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:9
verses.text: Apart from love, nothing is well pleasing to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:10
verses.text: "Of its perfection there is no unfolding," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:11
verses.text: "Who is fit to be found in it, except those whom God counts worthy?" To the point the Apostle Paul speaks, "If I give my body, and have not love, I am sounding brass, and a tinkling cymbal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:12
verses.text: If it is not from a disposition determined by gnostic love that I shall testify, he means;  but if through fear and expected reward, moving my lips in order to testify to the Lord that I shall confess the Lord, I am a common man, sounding the Lord's name, not knowing Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:13
verses.text: "For there is the people that loveth with the lips; and there is another which gives the body to be burned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:14
verses.text: "And if I give all my goods in alms," he says, not according to the principle of loving communication, but on account of recompense, either from him who has received the benefit, or the Lord who has promised; "and if I have all faith so as to remove mountains," and cast away obscuring passions, and be not faithful to the Lord from love, "I am nothing," as in comparison of him who testifies as a Gnostic, and the crowd, and being reckoned nothing better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:15
verses.text: "Now all the generations from Adam to this day are gone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:16
verses.text: But they who have been perfected in love, through the grace of God, hold the place of the godly, who shall be manifested at the visitation of the kingdom of Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:17
verses.text: Love permits not to sin; but if it fall into any such case, by reason of the interference of the adversary, in imitation of David, it will sing: "I will confess unto the Lord, and it will please Him above a young bullock that has horns and hoofs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:18
verses.text: Let the poor see it, and be glad".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:19
verses.text: For he says, "Sacrifice to God a sacrifice of praise, and pay to the Lord thy vows; and call upon me in the day of trouble, and I will deliver thee, and thou shalt glorify me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:20
verses.text: "For the sacrifice of God is a broken spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:21
verses.text: "God," then, being good, "is love," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:22
verses.text: Whose "love worketh no ill to his neighbour," neither injuring nor revenging ever, but, in a word, doing good to all according to the image of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:23
verses.text: "Love is," then, "the fulfilling of the law;" like as Christ, that is the presence of the Lord who loves us; and our loving teaching of, and discipline according to Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:24
verses.text: By love, then, the commands not to commit adultery, and not to covet one's neighbour's wife, are fulfilled, these sins being formerly prohibited by fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:25
verses.text: The same work, then, presents a difference, according as it is done by fear, or accomplished by love, and is wrought by faith or by knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:26
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, their rewards are different.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:27
verses.text: To the Gnostic "are prepared what eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, nor hath entered into the heart of man;" but to him who has exercised simple faith He testifies a hundredfold in return for what he has left,—a promise which has turned out to fall within human comprehension.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:28
verses.text: Come to this point, I recollect one who called himself a Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:29
verses.text: For, expounding the words, "But I say unto you, he that looketh on a woman to lust after, hath committed adultery," he thought that it was not bare desire that was condemned; but if through the desire the act that results from it proceeding beyond the desire is accomplished in it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:30
verses.text: For dream employs phantasy and the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:31
verses.text: Accordingly, the historians relate the following decision of Bocchoris the just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:32
verses.text: A youth, falling in love with a courtezan, persuades the girl, for a stipulated reward, to come to him next day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:33
verses.text: But his desire being unexpectedly satiated, by laying hold of the girl in a dream, by anticipation, when the object of his love came according to stipulation, he prohibited her from coming in.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:34
