verses.text: But she, on learning what had taken place, demanded the reward, saying that in this way she had sated the lover's desire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:35
verses.text: They came accordingly to the judge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:36
verses.text: He, ordering the youth to hold out the purse containing the reward in the sun, bade the courtezan take hold of the shadow; facetiously bidding him pay the image of a reward for the image of an embrace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:37
verses.text: Accordingly one dreams, the soul assenting to the vision.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:38
verses.text: But he dreams waking, who looks so as to lust; not only, as that Gnostic said, if along with the sight of the woman he imagine in his mind intercourse, for this is already the act of lust, as lust; but if one looks on beauty of person (the Word says), and the flesh seem to him in the way of lust to be fair, looking on carnally and sinfully, he is judged because he admired.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:39
verses.text: For, on the other hand, he who in chaste love looks on beauty, thinks not that the flesh is beautiful, but the spirit, admiring, as I judge, the body as an image, by whose beauty he transports himself to the Artist, and to the true beauty; exhibiting the sacred symbol, the bright impress of righteousness to the angels that wait on the ascension; I mean the unction of acceptance, the quality of disposition which resides in the soul that is gladdened by the communication of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:40
verses.text: This glory, which shone forth on the face of Moses, the people could not look on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:41
verses.text: Wherefore he took a veil for the glory, to those who looked carnally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:42
verses.text: For those, who demand toll, detain those who bring in any worldly things, who are burdened with their own passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:43
verses.text: But him that is free of all things which are subject to duty, and is full of knowledge, and of the righteousness of works, they pass on with their good wishes, blessing the man with his work.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:44
verses.text: "And his life shall not fall away"—the leaf of the living tree that is nourished "by the water-courses".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:45
verses.text: Now  the righteous is likened to fruit-bearing trees, and not only to such as are of the nature of tall-growing ones.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:46
verses.text: And in the sacrificial oblations, according to the law, there were those who looked for blemishes in the sacrifices.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 18:47
verses.text: They who are skilled in such matters distinguish propension (ὄρεξις) from lust (ἐπιθυμία); and assign the latter, as being irrational, to pleasures and licentiousness; and propension, as being a rational movement, they assign to the necessities of nature.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:1
verses.text: Chapter - 19—Women as well as Men Capable of Perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:2
verses.text: In this perfection it is possible for man and woman equally to share.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:3
verses.text: It is not only Moses, then, that heard from God, "I have spoken to thee once, and twice, saying, I have seen this people, and lo, it is stiff-necked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:4
verses.text: Suffer me to exterminate them, and blot out their name from under heaven; and I will make thee into a great and wonderful nation much greater than this;" who answers not regarding himself, but the common salvation: "By no means, O Lord; forgive this people their sin, or blot me out of the book of the living".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:5
verses.text: How great was his perfection, in wishing to die together with the people, rather than be saved alone!  But Judith too, who became perfect among women, in the siege of the city, at the entreaty of the elders went forth into the strangers' camp, despising all danger for her country's sake, giving herself into the enemy's hand in faith in God; and straightway she obtained the reward of her faith,—though a woman, prevailing over the enemy of her faith, and gaining possession of the head of Holofernes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:6
verses.text: And again, Esther perfect by faith, who rescued Israel from the power of the king and the satrap's cruelty: a woman alone, afflicted with fastings, held back ten thousand armed hands, annulling by her faith the tyrant's decree; him indeed she appeased, Haman she restrained, and Israel she preserved scathless by her perfect prayer to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:7
verses.text: I pass over in silence Susanna and the sister of Moses, since the latter was the prophet's associate in commanding the host, being superior to all the women among the Hebrews who were in repute for their wisdom; and the former in her surpassing modesty, going even to death condemned by licentious admirers, remained the unwavering martyr of chastity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:8
verses.text: Dion, too, the philosopher, tells that a certain woman Lysidica, through excess of modesty, bathed in her clothes; and that Philotera, when she was to enter the bath, gradually drew back her tunic as the water covered the naked parts; and then rising by degrees, put it on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:9
verses.text: And did not Leaena of Attica manfully bear the torture? She being privy to the conspiracy of Harmodius and Aristogeiton against Hipparchus, uttered not a word, though severely tortured.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:10
verses.text: And they say that the Argolic women, under the guidance of Telesilla the poetess, turned to flight the doughty Spartans by merely showing themselves; and that she produced in them fearlessness of death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:11
verses.text: Similarly speaks he who composed the Danais respecting the daughters of Danaus:—  "And then the daughters of Danaus swiftly armed themselves, Before the fair-flowing river, majestic Nile,"  and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:12
verses.text: And the rest of the poets sing of Atalanta's swiftness in the chase, of Anticlea's love for children, of Alcestis's love for her husband, of the courage of Makaeria and of the Hyacinthides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:13
verses.text: What shall I say? Did not Theano the Pythagorean make such progress in philosophy, that to him who looked intently at her, and said, "Your arm is beautiful," she answered "Yes, but it is not public".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:14
verses.text: Characterized by the same propriety, there is also reported the following reply.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:15
verses.text: When asked when a woman after being with her husband attends the Thesmophoria, said, "From her own husband at once, from a stranger never".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:16
verses.text: Themisto too, of Lampsacus, the daughter of Zoilus, the wife of Leontes of Lampsacus, studied the Epicurean philosophy, as Myia the daughter of Theano the Pythagorean, and Arignote, who wrote the history of Dionysius.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:17
verses.text: And the daughters of Diodorus, who was called Kronus, all became dialecticians, as Philo the dialectician says in the Menexenus, whose names are mentioned as follows—Menexene, Argia, Theognis, Artemesia, Pantaclea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:18
verses.text: I also recollect a female Cynic,—she was called Hipparchia, a Maronite, the wife of Crates,—in whose case the so-called dog-wedding was celebrated in the Poecile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:19
verses.text: Arete of Cyrene, too, the daughter of Aristippus, educated her son Aristippus, who was surnamed Mother-taught.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:20
verses.text: Lastheneia of Arcis, and Axiothea of Phlius, studied philosophy with Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:21
verses.text: Besides, Aspasia of Miletus, of whom the writers of comedy write much, was trained by Socrates in philosophy, by Pericles in rhetoric.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:22
verses.text: I omit, on account of the length of the discourse, the rest; enumerating neither the poetesses Corinna, Telesilla, Myia, and Sappho; nor the painters, as Irene the daughter of Cratinus, and Anaxandra the daughter of Nealces, according to the account of  Didymus in the Symposiaci.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:23
verses.text: The daughter of Cleobulus, the sage and monarch of the Lindii, was not ashamed to wash the feet of her father's guests.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:24
verses.text: Also the wife of Abraham, the blessed Sarah, in her own person prepared the cakes baked in the ashes for the angels; and princely maidens among the Hebrews fed sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:25
verses.text: Whence also the Nausicaä of Homer went to the washing-tubs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:26
verses.text: The wise woman, then, will first choose to persuade her husband to be her associate in what is conducive to happiness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:27
verses.text: And should that be found impracticable, let her by herself earnestly aim at virtue, gaining her husband's consent in everything, so as never to do anything against his will, with exception of what is reckoned as contributing to virtue and salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:28
verses.text: But if one keeps from such a mode of life either wife or maid-servant, whose heart is set on it; what such a person in that case plainly does is nothing else than determine to drive her away from righteousness and sobriety, and to choose to make his own house wicked and licentious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:29
verses.text: It is not then possible that man or woman can be conversant with anything whatever, without the advantage of education, and application, and training; and virtue, we have said, depends not on others, but on ourselves above all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:30
verses.text: Other things one can repress, by waging war against them; but with what depends on one's self, this is entirely out of the question, even with the most strenuous persistence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:31
verses.text: For the gift is one conferred by God, and not in the power of any other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 19:32
verses.text: Whence licentiousness should be regarded as the evil of no other one than of him who is guilty of licentiousness; and temperance, on the other hand, as the good of him who is able to practice it.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20—A Good Wife.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:2
verses.text: The woman who, with propriety, loves her husband, Euripides describes, while admonishing,—  "That when her husband says aught, She ought to regard him as speaking well if she say nothing; And if she will say anything, to do her endeavour to gratify her husband".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:3
verses.text: And again he subjoins the like:—  "And that the wife should sweetly look sad with her husband, Should aught evil befall him, And have in common a share of sorrow and joy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:4
verses.text: Then, describing her as gentle and kind even in misfortunes, he adds:—  "And I, when you are ill, will, sharing your sickness bear it; And I will bear my share in your misfortunes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:5
verses.text: And:—  "Nothing is bitter to me, For with friends one ought to be happy, For what else is friendship but this?"  The marriage, then, that is consummated according to the word, is sanctified, if the union be under subjection to God, and be conducted "with a true heart, in full assurance of faith, having hearts sprinkled from an evil conscience, and the body washed with pure water, and holding the confession of hope; for He is faithful that promised".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:6
verses.text: And the happiness of marriage ought never to be estimated either by wealth or beauty, but by virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:7
verses.text: "Beauty," says the tragedy,—  "Helps no wife with her husband; But virtue has helped many; for every good wife Who is attached to her husband knows how to practice sobriety".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:8
verses.text: Then, as giving admonitions, he says:—  "First, then, this is incumbent on her who is endowed with mind, That even if her husband be ugly, he must appear good-looking; For it is for the mind, not the eye, to judge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:9
verses.text: And so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:10
verses.text: For with perfect propriety Scripture has said that woman is given by God as "an help" to man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:11
verses.text: It is evident, then, in my opinion, that she will charge herself with remedying, by good sense and persuasion, each of the annoyances that originate with her husband in domestic economy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:12
verses.text: And if he do not yield, then she will endeavour, as far as possible for human nature, to lead a sinless life; whether it be necessary to die, in accordance with reason, or to live; considering that God is her helper and associate in such a course of conduct, her true defender and Saviour both for the present and for the future; making Him the leader and guide of all her actions, reckoning sobriety and righteousness her work, and making the favour of God her end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:13
verses.text: Gracefully, therefore, the apostle says in the Epistle to Titus, "that the elder women should be of godly behaviour, should not be slanderers, not enslaved to much wine; that they should counsel the young women to be lovers of their husbands, lovers of their children, discreet, chaste, housekeepers, good, subject to their own husbands; that the word of God be not blasphemed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:14
verses.text: But rather, he says, "Follow peace with all men, and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord: looking diligently, lest there be any fornicator or profane person, as Esau, who for one morsel surrendered his birth-right; and lest any root of bitterness springing up trouble you, and thereby many be defiled".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:15
verses.text: And then, as putting the finishing stroke to the question about marriage, he adds: "Marriage is honourable in all, and the bed undefiled: but whoremongers and adulterers God will judge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:16
verses.text: And one aim and one end, as far as regards perfection, being demonstrated to belong to the man and the woman, Peter in his Epistle says, "Though now for a season, if need be, ye are in heaviness through manifold temptations; that the trial of your faith, being much more precious than that of gold which perisheth, though it be tried with fire, might be found unto praise, and honour, and glory at the revelation of Jesus Christ; whom, having not seen, ye love; in whom, though now ye see Him not, yet believing, ye rejoice with joy unspeakable, and full of glory, receiving the end of your faith, the salvation of your souls".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 20:17
verses.text: Wherefore also Paul rejoices for Christ's sake that he was "in labours, more abundantly, in stripes above measure, in deaths oft".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21—Description of the Perfect Man, or Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:2
verses.text: Here I find perfection apprehended variously in relation to Him who excels in every virtue.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:3
verses.text: Accordingly one is perfected as pious, and as patient, and as continent, and as a worker, and as a martyr, and as a Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:4
verses.text: But I know no one of men perfect in all things at once, while still human, though according to the mere letter of the law, except Him alone who for us clothed Himself with humanity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:5
verses.text: Who then is perfect? He who professes abstinence from what is bad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:6
verses.text: Well, this is the way to the Gospel and to well-doing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:7
verses.text: But gnostic perfection in the case of the legal man is the acceptance of the Gospel, that he that is after the law may be perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:8
verses.text: For so he, who was after the law, Moses, foretold that it was necessary to hear in order that we might, according to the apostle, receive Christ, the fulness of the law.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:9
verses.text: But now in the Gospel the Gnostic attains proficiency not only by making use of the law as a step, but by understanding and comprehending it, as the Lord who gave the Covenants delivered it to the apostles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:10
verses.text: And if he conduct himself rightly (as assuredly it is impossible to attain knowledge (gnosis) by bad conduct); and if, further, having made an eminently right confession, he become a martyr out of love, obtaining considerable renown as among men; not even thus will he be called perfect in the flesh beforehand; since it is the close of life which claims this appellation, when the gnostic martyr has first shown the perfect work, and rightly exhibited it, and having thankfully shed his blood, has yielded up the ghost: blessed then will he be, and truly proclaimed perfect, "that the excellency of the power may be of God, and not of us," as the apostle says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:11
verses.text: Only let us preserve free-will and love: "troubled on every side, yet not distressed; perplexed, but not in despair; persecuted, but not forsaken; cast down, but not destroyed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:12
verses.text: For those who strive after perfection, according to the same apostle, must "give no offence in anything, but in everything approve themselves not to men, but to God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:13
verses.text: And, as a consequence, also they ought to yield to men; for it is reasonable, on account of abusive calumnies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:14
verses.text: Here is the specification: "in much patience, in afflictions, in necessities, in distresses, in stripes, in imprisonments, in tumults, in labours, in watchings, in fastings, in pureness, in knowledge, in long-suffering, in kindness, in the Holy Ghost, in love unfeigned, in the word of truth, in the power of God," that we may be the temples of God, purified "from all filthiness of the flesh and of the spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:15
verses.text: "And I," He says, "will receive you; and I will be to you for a Father, and ye shall be to Me for sons and daughters, saith the Lord Almighty".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:16
verses.text: "Let us then," he says, "perfect holiness in the fear of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:17
verses.text: For though fear beget pain, "I rejoice," he says, "not that ye were made sorry, but that ye showed susceptibility to repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:18
verses.text: For ye sorrowed after a godly sort, that ye might receive damage by us in nothing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:19
verses.text: For godly sorrow worketh repentance unto salvation not to be regretted; but the sorrow of the world worketh death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:20
verses.text: For this same thing that ye sorrowed after a godly sort, what earnestness it wrought in you; yea, what clearing of yourselves; yea, what compunction; yea, what fear; yea, what desire; yea, what zeal; yea, revenge! In all things ye have showed yourselves clear in the matter".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:21
verses.text: Such are the preparatory exercises of gnostic discipline.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:22
verses.text: And since the omnipotent God Himself "gave some apostles, and some prophets, and some evangelists, and some pastors and teachers, for the perfecting of the saints, for the work of the ministry, for the edifying of the body of Christ, till we all attain to the unity of the faith, and of the knowledge of the Son of God, to a perfect man, to the measure of the stature of the fulness of Christ;" we are then to strive to reach manhood as befits the Gnostic, and to be as perfect as we can while still abiding in the flesh, making it our study with perfect concord here to concur with the will of God, to the restoration of what is the truly perfect nobleness and relationship, to the fulness of Christ, that which perfectly depends on our perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:23
verses.text: And now we perceive where, and how, and when the divine apostle mentions the perfect man, and how he shows the differences of the perfect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:24
verses.text: And again, on the other hand: "The  manifestation of the Spirit is given for our profit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:25
verses.text: For to one is given the word of wisdom by the Spirit; to another the word of knowledge according to the same Spirit; to another faith through the same Spirit; to another the gifts of healing through the same Spirit; to another the working of miracles; to another prophecy; to another discernment of spirits; to another diversities of tongues; to another the interpretation of tongues: and all these worketh the one and the same Spirit, distributing to each one according as He wills".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:26
verses.text: Such being the case, the prophets are perfect in prophecy, the righteous in righteousness, and the martyrs in confession, and others in preaching, not that they are not sharers in the common virtues, but are proficient in those to which they are appointed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:27
verses.text: For what man in his senses would say that a prophet was not righteous? For what? did not righteous men like Abraham prophesy?  "For to one God has given warlike deeds, To another the accomplishment of the dance, To another the lyre and song,"  says Homer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:28
verses.text: "But each has his own proper gift of God"—one in one way, another in another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:29
verses.text: But the apostles were perfected in all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:30
verses.text: You will find, then, if you choose, in their acts and writings, knowledge, life, preaching, righteousness, purity, prophecy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:31
verses.text: We must know, then, that if Paul is young in respect to time—having flourished immediately after the Lord's ascension—yet his writings depend on the Old Testament, breathing and speaking of them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 21:32
verses.text: For faith in Christ and the knowledge of the Gospel are the explanation and fulfilment of the law; and therefore it was said to the Hebrews, "If ye believe not, neither shall you understand;" that is, unless you believe what is prophesied in the law, and oracularly delivered by the law, you will not understand the Old Testament, which He by His coming expounded.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 22—The True Gnostic Does Good, Not from Fear of Punishment or Hope of Reward, But Only for the Sake of Good Itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:2
verses.text: The man of understanding and perspicacity is, then, a Gnostic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:3
verses.text: And his business is not abstinence from what is evil (for this is a step to the highest perfection), or the doing of good out of fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:4
verses.text: For it is written, "Whither shall I flee, and where shall I hide myself from Thy presence? If I ascend into heaven, Thou art there; if I go away to the uttermost parts of the sea, there is Thy right hand; if I go down into the depths, there is Thy Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:5
verses.text: Nor any more is he to do so from hope of promised recompense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:6
verses.text: For it is said, "Behold the Lord, and His reward is before His face, to give to every one according to his works; what eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and hath not entered into the heart of man what God hath prepared for them that love Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:7
verses.text: But only the doing of good out of love, and for the sake of its own excellence, is to be the Gnostic's choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:8
verses.text: Now, in the person of God it is said to the Lord, "Ask of Me, and I will give the heathen for Thine inheritance;" teaching Him to ask a truly regal request—that is, the salvation of men without price, that we may inherit and possess the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:9
verses.text: For, on the contrary, to desire knowledge about God for any practical purpose, that this may be done, or that may not be done, is not proper to the Gnostic; but the knowledge itself suffices as the reason for contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:10
verses.text: For I will dare aver that it is not because he wishes to be saved that he, who devotes himself to knowledge for the sake of the divine science itself, chooses knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:11
verses.text: For the exertion of the intellect by exercise is prolonged to a perpetual exertion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:12
verses.text: And the perpetual exertion of the intellect is the essence of an intelligent being, which results from an uninterrupted process of admixture, and remains eternal contemplation, a living substance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:13
verses.text: Could we, then, suppose any one proposing to the Gnostic whether he would choose the knowledge of God or everlasting salvation; and if these, which are entirely identical, were separable, he would without the least hesitation choose the knowledge of God, deeming that property of faith, which from love ascends to knowledge, desirable, for its own sake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:14
verses.text: This, then, is the perfect man's first form of doing good, when it is done not for any advantage in what pertains to him, but because he judges it right to do good; and the energy being vigorously exerted in all things, in the very act becomes good; not, good in some things, and not good in others; but consisting in the habit of doing good, neither for glory, nor, as the philosophers say, for reputation, nor from reward either from men or God; but so as to pass life after the image and likeness of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:15
verses.text: And if, in doing good, he be met with anything adverse, he will let the recompense pass without resentment as if it were good, he being just and good "to the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:16
verses.text: To such the Lord says, "Be ye, as your Father is perfect".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:17
verses.text: To him the flesh is dead; but he himself lives alone, having consecrated the sepulchre into a holy temple to the Lord, having turned towards God the old sinful soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:18
verses.text: Such an one is no longer continent, but has  reached a state of passionlessness, waiting to put on the divine image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:19
verses.text: "If thou doest alms," it is said, "let no one know it; and if thou fastest, anoint thyself, that God alone may know," and not a single human being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:20
verses.text: Not even he himself who shows mercy ought to know that he does show mercy; for in this way he will be sometimes merciful, sometimes not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:21
verses.text: And when he shall do good by habit, he will imitate the nature of good, and his disposition will be his nature and his practice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:22
verses.text: There is no necessity for removing those who are raised on high, but there is necessity for those who are walking to reach the requisite goal, by passing over the whole of the narrow way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:23
verses.text: For this is to be drawn by the Father, to become worthy to receive the power of grace from God, so as to run without hindrance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:24
verses.text: And if some hate the elect, such an one knows their ignorance, and pities their minds for its folly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:25
verses.text: As is right, then, knowledge itself loves and teaches the ignorant, and instructs the whole creation to honour God Almighty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:26
verses.text: And if such an one teaches to love God, he will not hold virtue as a thing to be lost in any case, either awake or in a dream, or in any vision; since the habit never goes out of itself by falling from being a habit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:27
verses.text: Whether, then, knowledge be said to be habit or disposition; on account of diverse sentiments never obtaining access, the guiding faculty, remaining unaltered, admits no alteration of appearances by framing in dreams visionary conceptions out of its movements by day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:28
verses.text: Wherefore also the Lord enjoins "to watch," so that our soul may never be perturbed with passion, even in dreams; but also to keep the life of the night pure and stainless, as if spent in the day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:29
verses.text: For assimilation to God, as far as we can, is preserving the mind in its relation to the same things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:30
verses.text: And this is the relation of mind as mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:31
verses.text: But the variety of disposition arises from inordinate affection to material things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:32
verses.text: And for this reason, as they appear to me, to have called night Euphrone; since then the soul, released from the perceptions of sense, turns in on itself, and has a truer hold of intelligence (φρόνησις).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:33
verses.text: Wherefore the mysteries are for the most part celebrated by night, indicating the withdrawal of the soul from the body, which takes place by night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:34
verses.text: "Let us not then sleep, as do others; but let us watch and be sober.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:35
verses.text: For they that sleep, sleep in the night; and they that are drunken, are drunken in the night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:36
verses.text: But let us who are of the day be sober, putting on the breastplate of faith and love, and as an helmet the hope of salvation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:37
verses.text: And as to what, again, they say of sleep, the very same things are to be understood of death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:38
verses.text: For each exhibits the departure of the soul, the one more, the other less; as we may also get this in Heraclitus: "Man touches night in himself, when dead and his light quenched; and alive, when he sleeps he touches the dead; and awake, when he shuts his eyes, he touches the sleeper".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:39
verses.text: "For blessed are those that have seen the Lord," according to the apostle; "for it is high time to awake out of sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:40
verses.text: For now is our salvation nearer than when we believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:41
verses.text: The night is far spent, the day is at hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:42
verses.text: Let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and put on the armour of light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:43
verses.text: By day and light he designates figuratively the Son, and by the armour of light metaphorically the promises.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:44
verses.text: So it is said that we ought to go washed to sacrifices and prayers, clean and bright; and that this external adornment and purification are practiced for a sign.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:45
verses.text: Now purity is to think holy thoughts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:46
verses.text: Further, there is the image of baptism, which also was handed down to the poets from Moses as follows:—  "And she having drawn water, and wearing on her body clean clothes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:47
verses.text: It is Penelope that is going to prayer:—  "And Telemachus, Having washed his hands in the hoary sea, prayed to Athene".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:48
verses.text: It was a custom of the Jews to wash frequently after being in bed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:49
verses.text: It was then well said,—  "Be pure, not by washing of water, but in the mind".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:50
verses.text: For sanctity, as I conceive it, is perfect pureness of mind, and deeds, and thoughts, and words too, and in its last degree sinlessness in dreams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:51
verses.text: And sufficient purification to a man, I reckon, is thorough and sure repentance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:52
verses.text: If, condemning ourselves for our former actions, we go forward, after these things taking thought, and divesting our mind both of the things which please us through the senses, and of our former transgressions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:53
verses.text: If, then, we are to give the etymology of ἐπιστήμη, knowledge, its signification is to be derived from στάσις, placing; for our soul, which was formerly borne, now in one way, now in another, it settles in objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:54
verses.text: Similarly faith is to be explained etymologically, as the settling (στάσις) of our soul respecting that which is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:55
verses.text: But we desire to learn about the man who is always and in all things righteous; who, neither dreading the penalty proceeding from the law,  nor fearing to entertain hatred of evil in the case of those who live with him and who prosecute the injured, nor dreading danger at the hands of those who do wrong, remains righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:56
verses.text: For he who, on account of these considerations, abstains from anything wrong, is not voluntarily kind, but is good from fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:57
verses.text: Even Epicurus says, that the man who in his estimation was wise, "would not do wrong to any one for the sake of gain; for he could not persuade himself that he would escape detection".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:58
verses.text: So that, if he knew he would not be detected, he would, according to him, do evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:59
verses.text: And such are the doctrines of darkness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:60
verses.text: If, too, one shall abstain from doing wrong from hope of the recompense given by God on account of righteous deeds, he is not on this supposition spontaneously good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:61
verses.text: For as fear makes that man just, so reward makes this one; or rather, makes him appear to be just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:62
verses.text: But with the hope after death—a good hope to the good, to the bad the reverse—not only they who follow after Barbarian wisdom, but also the Pythagoreans, are acquainted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:63
verses.text: For the latter also proposed hope as an end to those who philosophize.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:64
verses.text: Whereas Socrates also, in the Phaedo, says "that good souls depart hence with a good hope;" and again, denouncing the wicked, he sets against this the assertion, "For they live with an evil hope".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:65
verses.text: With him Heraclitus manifestly agrees in his dissertations concerning men: "There awaits man after death what they neither hope nor think".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:66
verses.text: Divinely, therefore, Paul writes expressly, "Tribulation worketh, patience, and patience experience, and experience hope; and hope maketh not ashamed".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:67
verses.text: For the patience is on account of the hope in the future.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:68
verses.text: Now hope is synonymous with the recompense and restitution of hope; which maketh not ashamed, not being any more vilified.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:69
verses.text: But he who obeys the mere call, as he is called, neither for fear, nor for enjoyments, is on his way to knowledge (γνῶσις).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:70
verses.text: For he does not consider whether any extrinsic lucrative gain or enjoyment follows to him; but drawn by the love of Him who is the true object of love, and led to what is requisite, practices piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:71
verses.text: So that not even were we to suppose him to receive from God leave to do things forbidden with impunity; not even if he were to get the promise that he would receive as a reward the good things of the blessed; but besides, not even if he could persuade himself that God would be hoodwinked with reference to what he does (which is impossible), would he ever wish to do aught contrary to right reason, having once made choice of what is truly good and worthy of choice on its own account, and therefore to be loved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:72
verses.text: For it is not in the food of the belly, that we have heard good to be situated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:73
verses.text: But he has heard that "meat will not commend us," nor marriage, nor abstinence from marriage in ignorance; but virtuous gnostic conduct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:74
verses.text: For the dog, which is an irrational animal, may be said to be continent, dreading as it does the uplifted stick, and therefore keeping away from the meat.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 22:75
verses.text: But let the predicted promise be taken away, and the threatened dread cancelled, and the impending danger removed, and the disposition of such people will be revealed.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—The Same Subject Continued.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:2
verses.text: For it is not suitable to the nature of the thing itself, that they should apprehend in the truly gnostic manner the truth, that all things which were created for our use are good; as, for example, marriage and procreation, when used in moderation; and that it is better than good to become free of passion, and virtuous by assimilation to the divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:3
verses.text: But in the case of external things, agreeable or disagreeable, from some they abstain, from others not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:4
verses.text: But in those things from which they abstain from disgust, they plainly find fault with the creature and the Creator; and though in appearance they walk faithfully, the opinion they maintain is impious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:5
verses.text: That command, "Thou shall not lust," needs neither the necessity arising from fear, which compels to keep from things that are pleasant; nor the reward, which by promise persuades to restrain the impulses of passion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:6
verses.text: And those who obey God through the promise, caught by the bait of pleasure, choose obedience not for the sake of the commandment, but for the sake of the promise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:7
verses.text: Nor will turning away from objects of sense, as a matter of necessary consequence, produce attachment to intellectual objects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:8
verses.text: On the contrary, the attachment to intellectual objects naturally becomes to the Gnostic an influence which draws away from the objects of sense; inasmuch as he, in virtue of the selection of what is good, has chosen what is good according to knowledge (γνωστικῶς), admiring generation, and by sanctifying the Creator sanctifying assimilation to the divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:9
verses.text: But I shall free myself from lust, let him say, O Lord, for the sake of alliance with Thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:10
verses.text: For the economy of creation is good, and all things are well administered: nothing happens without a cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:11
verses.text: I must be in what is Thine, O Omnipotent One.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:12
verses.text: And if I am there, I am near Thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:13
verses.text: And I would be free of fear that I may be able to draw near to Thee, and to be satisfied with little, practising Thy just choice between things good and things like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:14
verses.text: Right mystically and sacredly the apostle, teaching us the choice which is truly gracious,  not in the way of rejection of other things as bad, but so as to do things better than what is good, has spoken, saying, "So he that giveth his virgin in marriage doeth well; and he that giveth her not doeth better; as far as respects seemliness and undistracted attendance on the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:15
verses.text: Now we know that things which are difficult are not essential; but that things which are essential have been graciously made easy of attainment by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:16
verses.text: Wherefore Democritus well says, that "nature and instruction" are like each other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:17
verses.text: And we have briefly assigned the cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:18
verses.text: For instruction harmonizes man, and by harmonizing makes him natural; and it is no matter whether one was made such as he is by nature, or transformed by time and education.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:19
verses.text: The Lord has furnished both; that which is by creation, and that which is by creating again and renewal through the covenant.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:20
verses.text: And that is preferable which is advantageous to what is superior; but what is superior to everything is mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:21
verses.text: So, then, what is really good is seen to be most pleasant, and of itself produces the fruit which is desired—tranquillity of soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:22
verses.text: "And he who hears Me," it is said, "shall rest in peace, confident, and shall be calm without fear of any evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:23
verses.text: "Rely with all thy heart and thy mind on God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:24
verses.text: On this wise it is possible for the Gnostic already to have become God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:25
verses.text: "I said, Ye are gods, and sons of the highest".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:26
verses.text: And Empedocles says that the souls of the wise become gods, writing as follows:—  "At last prophets, minstrels, and physicians, And the foremost among mortal men, approach; Whence spring gods supreme in honours".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:27
verses.text: Man, then, genetically considered, is formed in accordance with the idea of the connate spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:28
verses.text: For he is not created formless and shapeless in the workshop of nature, where mystically the production of man is accomplished, both art and essence being common.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:29
verses.text: But the individual man is stamped according to the impression produced in the soul by the objects of his choice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:30
verses.text: Thus we say that Adam was perfect, as far as respects his formation; for none of the distinctive characteristics of the idea and form of man were wanting to him; but in the act of coming into being he received perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:31
verses.text: And he was justified by obedience; this was reaching manhood, as far as depended on him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:32
verses.text: And the cause lay in his choosing, and especially in his choosing what was forbidden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:33
verses.text: God was not the cause.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:34
verses.text: For production is twofold—of things procreated, and of things that grow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:35
verses.text: And manliness in man, who is subject to perturbation, as they say, makes him who partakes of it essentially fearless and invincible; and anger is the mind's satellite in patience, and endurance, and the like; and self-constraint and salutary sense are set over desire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:36
verses.text: But God is impassible, free of anger, destitute of desire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:37
verses.text: And He is not free of fear, in the sense of avoiding what is terrible; or temperate, in the sense of having command of desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:38
verses.text: For neither can the nature of God fall in with anything terrible, nor does God flee fear; just as He will not feel desire, so as to rule over desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:39
verses.text: Accordingly that Pythagorean saying was mystically uttered respecting us, "that man ought to become one;" for the high priest himself is one, God being one in the immutable state of the perpetual flow of good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:40
verses.text: Now the Saviour has taken away wrath in and with lust, wrath being lust of vengeance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:41
verses.text: For universally liability to feeling belongs to every kind of desire; and man, when deified purely into a passionless state, becomes a unit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:42
verses.text: As, then, those, who at sea are held by an anchor, pull at the anchor, but do not drag it to them, but drag themselves to the anchor; so those who, according to the gnostic life, draw God towards them, imperceptibly bring themselves to God: for he who reverences God, reverences himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 23:43
verses.text: In the contemplative life, then, one in worshipping God attends to himself, and through his own spotless purification beholds the holy God holily; for self-control, being present, surveying and contemplating itself uninterruptedly, is as far as possible assimilated to God.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 24—The Reason and End of Divine Punishments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:2
verses.text: Now that is in our power, of which equally with its opposite we are masters,—as, say to philosophize or not, to believe or disbelieve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:3
verses.text: In consequence, then, of our being equally masters of each of the opposites, what depends on us is found possible.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:4
verses.text: Now the commandments may be done or not done by us, who, as is reasonable, are liable to praise and blame.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:5
verses.text: And those, again, who are punished on account of sins committed by them, are punished for them alone; for what is done is past, and what is done can never be undone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:6
verses.text: The sins committed before faith are accordingly forgiven by the Lord, not that they may be undone, but as if they had not been done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:7
verses.text: "But not all," says Basilides, "but only sins involuntary and in ignorance, are forgiven;" as would be the case were it a man, and not God, that conferred such a boon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:8
verses.text: To such an one Scripture says, "Thou thoughtest that I would be like thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:9
verses.text: But if we are punished  for voluntary sins, we are punished not that the sins which are done may be undone, but because they were done.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:10
verses.text: But punishment does not avail to him who has sinned, to undo his sin, but that he may sin no more, and that no one else fall into the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:11
verses.text: Therefore the good God corrects for these three causes: First, that he who is corrected may become better than his former self; then that those who are capable of being saved by examples may be driven back, being admonished; and thirdly, that he who is injured may not be readily despised, and be apt to receive injury.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:12
verses.text: And there are two methods of correction—the instructive and the punitive, which we have called the disciplinary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:13
verses.text: It ought to be known, then, that those who fall into sin after baptism are those who are subjected to discipline; for the deeds done before are remitted, and those done after are purged.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 24:14
verses.text: It is in reference to the unbelieving that it is said, "that they are reckoned as the chaff which the wind drives from the face of the earth, and the drop which falls from a vessel".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 25—True Perfection Consists in the Knowledge and Love of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:2
verses.text: "Happy he who possesses the culture of knowledge, and is not moved to the injury of the citizens or to wrong actions, but contemplates the undecaying order of immortal nature, how and in what way and manner it subsists.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:3
verses.text: To such the practice of base deeds attaches not," Rightly, then, Plato says, "that the man who devotes himself to the contemplation of ideas will live as a god among men; now the mind is the place of ideas, and God is mind".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:4
verses.text: He says that he who contemplates the unseen God lives as a god among men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:5
verses.text: And in the Sophist, Socrates calls the stranger of Elea, who was a dialectician, "god:" "Such are the gods who, like stranger guests, frequent cities.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:6
verses.text: For when the soul, rising above the sphere of generation, is by itself apart, and dwells amidst ideas," like the Coryphaeus in Theaetetus, now become as an angel, it will be with Christ, being rapt in contemplation, ever keeping in view the will of God; in reality  "Alone wise, while these flit like shadows".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:7
verses.text: "For the dead bury their dead".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:8
verses.text: Whence Jeremiah says: "I will fill it with the earth-born dead whom mine anger has smitten".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:9
verses.text: God, then, being not a subject for demonstration, cannot be the object of science.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:10
verses.text: But the Son is wisdom, and knowledge, and truth, and all else that has affinity thereto.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:11
verses.text: He is also susceptible of demonstration and of description.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:12
verses.text: And all the powers of the Spirit, becoming collectively one thing, terminate in the same point—that is, in the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:13
verses.text: But He is incapable of being declared, in respect of the idea of each one of His powers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:14
verses.text: And the Son is neither simply one thing as one thing, nor many things as parts, but one thing as all things; whence also He is all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:15
verses.text: For He is the circle of all powers rolled and united into one unity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:16
verses.text: Wherefore the Word is called the Alpha and the Omega, of whom alone the end becomes beginning, and ends again at the original beginning without any break.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:17
verses.text: Wherefore also to believe in Him, and by Him, is to become a unit, being indissolubly united in Him; and to disbelieve is to be separated, disjoined, divided.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:18
verses.text: "Wherefore thus saith the Lord, Every alien son is uncircumcised in heart, and uncircumcised in flesh" (that is, unclean in body and soul): "there shall not enter one of the strangers into the midst of the house of Israel, but the Levites".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:19
verses.text: He calls those that would not believe, but would disbelieve, strangers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:20
verses.text: Only those who live purely being true priests of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:21
verses.text: Wherefore, of all the circumcised tribes, those anointed to be high priests, and kings, and prophets, were reckoned more holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:22
verses.text: Whence He commands them not to touch dead bodies, or approach the dead; not that the body was polluted, but that sin and disobedience were incarnate, and embodied, and dead, and therefore abominable.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:23
verses.text: It was only, then, when a father and mother, a son and daughter died, that the priest was allowed to enter, because these were related only by flesh and seed, to whom the priest was indebted for the immediate cause of his entrance into life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:24
verses.text: And they purify themselves seven days, the period in which Creation was consummated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:25
verses.text: For on the seventh day the rest is celebrated; and on the eighth he brings a propitiation, as is written in Ezekiel, according to which propitiation the promise is to be received.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:26
verses.text: And the perfect propitiation, I take it, is that propitious faith in the Gospel which is by the law and the prophets, and the purity which shows itself in universal obedience, with the abandonment of the things of the world; in order to that grateful surrender of the tabernacle, which results from the enjoyment of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:27
verses.text: Whether, then, the time be that which through the seven periods enumerated returns to the chiefest rest, or the seven heavens, which some reckon one above the other; or whether also the fixed sphere which borders on the intellectual world be called the eighth, the expression denotes that the Gnostic ought to rise out of the sphere of creation and of sin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:28
verses.text: After these seven days, sacrifices are offered for sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:29
verses.text: For there is still fear of  change, and it touches the seventh circle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:30
verses.text: The righteous Job says: "Naked came I out of my mother's womb, and naked shall I return there;" not naked of possessions, for that were a trivial and common thing; but, as a just man, he departs naked of evil and sin, and of the unsightly shape which follows those who have led bad lives.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:31
verses.text: For this was what was said, "Unless ye be converted, and become as children," pure in flesh, holy in soul by abstinence from evil deeds; showing that He would have us to be such as also He generated us from our mother—the water.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:32
verses.text: For the intent of one generation succeeding another is to immortalize by progress.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:33
verses.text: "But the lamp of the wicked shall be put out".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:34
verses.text: That purity in body and soul which the Gnostic partakes of, the all-wise Moses indicated, by employing repetition in describing the incorruptibility of body and of soul in the person of Rebecca, thus: "Now the virgin was fair, and man had not known her".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:35
verses.text: And Rebecca, interpreted, means "glory of God;" and the glory of God is immortality.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:36
verses.text: This is in reality righteousness, not to desire other things, but to be entirely the consecrated temple of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:37
verses.text: Righteousness is peace of life and a well-conditioned state, to which the Lord dismissed her when He said, "Depart into peace".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:38
verses.text: For Salem is, by interpretation, peace; of which our Saviour is enrolled King, as Moses says, Melchizedek king of Salem, priest of the most high God, who gave bread and wine, furnishing consecrated food for a type of the Eucharist.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:39
verses.text: And Melchizedek is interpreted "righteous king;" and the name is a synonym for righteousness and peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:40
verses.text: Basilides, however, supposes that Righteousness and her daughter Peace dwell stationed in the eighth sphere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:41
verses.text: But we must pass from physics to ethics, which are clearer; for the discourse concerning these will follow after the treatise in hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:42
verses.text: The Saviour Himself, then, plainly initiates us into the mysteries, according to the words of the tragedy:—  "Seeing those who see, he also gives the orgies".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:43
verses.text: And if you ask,  "These orgies, what is their nature?"  You will hear again:—  "It is forbidden to mortals uninitiated in the Bacchic rites to know".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:44
verses.text: And if any one will inquire curiously what they are, let him hear:—  "It is not lawful for thee to hear, but they are worth knowing; The rites of the God detest him who practices impiety".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:45
verses.text: Now God, who is without beginning, is the perfect beginning of the universe, and the producer of the beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:46
verses.text: As, then, He is being, He is the first principle of the department of action, as He is good, of morals; as He is mind, on the other hand, He is the first principle of reasoning and of judgment.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 25:47
verses.text: Whence also He alone is Teacher, who is the only Son of the Most High Father, the Instructor of men.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 26—How the Perfect Man Treats the Body and the Things of the World.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:2
verses.text: Those, then, who run down created existence and vilify the body are wrong; not considering that the frame of man was formed erect for the contemplation of heaven, and that the organization of the senses tends to knowledge; and that the members and parts are arranged for good, not for pleasure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:3
verses.text: Whence this abode becomes receptive of the soul which is most precious to God; and is dignified with the Holy Spirit through the sanctification of soul and body, perfected with the perfection of the Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:4
verses.text: And the succession of the three virtues is found in the Gnostic, who morally, physically, and logically occupies himself with God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:5
verses.text: For wisdom is the knowledge of things divine and human; and righteousness is the concord of the parts of the soul; and holiness is the service of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:6
verses.text: But if one were to say that he disparaged the flesh, and generation on account of it, by quoting Isaiah, who says, "All flesh is grass, and all the glory of man as the flower of grass: the grass is withered, and the flower has fallen; but the word of the Lord endureth for ever;" let him hear the Spirit interpreting the matter in question by Jeremiah, "And I scattered them like dry sticks, that are made to fly by the wind into the desert.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:7
verses.text: This is the lot and portion of your disobedience, saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:8
verses.text: As thou hast forgotten Me, and hast trusted in lies, so will I discover thy hinder parts to thy face; and thy disgrace shall be seen, thy adultery, and thy neighing," and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:9
verses.text: For "the flower of grass," and "walking after the flesh," and "being carnal," according to the apostle, are those who are in their sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:10
verses.text: The soul of man is confessedly the better part of man, and the body the inferior.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:11
verses.text: But neither is the soul good by nature, nor, on the other hand, is the body bad by nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:12
verses.text: Nor is that which is not good straightway bad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:13
verses.text: For there are things which occupy a middle place, and among them are things to be preferred, and things to be rejected.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:14
verses.text: The constitution of man, then, which has its place among things of sense, was necessarily composed of things diverse, but not opposite—body and soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:15
verses.text: Always therefore the good actions, as better, attach to the better and ruling spirit; and voluptuous and sinful actions are attributed to the worse, the sinful one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:16
verses.text: Now the soul of the wise man and Gnostic, as sojourning in the body, conducts itself towards it gravely and respectfully, not with inordinate affections, as about to leave the tabernacle if the time of departure summon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:17
verses.text: "I am a stranger in the earth, and a sojourner with you," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:18
verses.text: And hence Basilides says, that he apprehends that the election are strangers to the world, being supramundane by nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:19
verses.text: But this is not the case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:20
verses.text: For all things are of one God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:21
verses.text: And no one is a stranger to the world by nature, their essence being one, and God one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:22
verses.text: But the elect man dwells as a sojourner, knowing all things to be possessed and disposed of; and he makes use of the things which the Pythagoreans make out to be the threefold good things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:23
verses.text: The body, too, as one sent on a distant pilgrimage, uses inns and dwellings by the way, having care of the things of the world, of the places where he halts; but leaving his dwelling-place and property without excessive emotion; readily following him that leads him away from life; by no means and on no occasion turning back; giving thanks for his sojourn, and blessing God for his departure, embracing the mansion that is in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:24
verses.text: "For we know, that, if the earthly house of our tabernacle be dissolved, we have a building of God, an house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:25
verses.text: For we that are in this tabernacle do groan, desiring to be clothed upon with our house which is from heaven: if so be that being clothed we shall not be found naked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:26
verses.text: For we walk by faith, not by sight," as the apostle says; "and we are willing rather to be absent from the body, and present with God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:27
verses.text: The rather is in comparison.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:28
verses.text: And comparison obtains in the case of things that fall under resemblance; as the more valiant man is more valiant among the valiant, and most valiant among cowards.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:29
verses.text: Whence he adds, "Wherefore we strive, whether present or absent, to be accepted with Him," that is, God, whose work and creation are all things, both the world and things supramundane.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:30
verses.text: I admire Epicharmus, who clearly says:—  "Endowed with pious mind, you will not, in dying, Suffer aught evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:31
verses.text: The spirit will dwell in heaven above;"  and the minstrel who sings:—  "The souls of the wicked flit about below the skies on earth, In murderous pains beneath inevitable yokes of evils; But those of the pious dwell in the heavens, Hymning in songs the Great, the Blessed One".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:32
verses.text: The soul is not then sent down from heaven to what is worse.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:33
verses.text: For God works all things up to what is better.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:34
verses.text: But the soul which has chosen the best life—the life that is from God and righteousness—exchanges earth for heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:35
verses.text: With reason therefore, Job, who had attained to knowledge, said, "Now I know that thou canst do all things; and nothing is impossible to Thee.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:36
verses.text: For who tells me of what I know not, great and wonderful things with which I was unacquainted? And I felt myself vile, considering myself to be earth and ashes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:37
verses.text: For he who, being in a state of ignorance, is sinful, "is earth and ashes;" while he who is in a state of knowledge, being assimilated as far as possible to God, is already spiritual, and so elect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:38
verses.text: And that Scripture calls the senseless and disobedient "earth," will be made clear by Jeremiah the prophet, saying, in reference to Joachim and his brethren "Earth, earth, hear the word of the Lord; Write this man, as man excommunicated".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:39
verses.text: And another prophet says again, "Hear, O heaven; and give ear, O earth," calling understanding "ear," and the soul of the Gnostic, that of the man who has applied himself to the contemplation of heaven and divine things, and in this way has become an Israelite, "heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:40
verses.text: For again he calls him who has made ignorance and hardness of heart his choice, "earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:41
verses.text: And the expression "give ear" he derives from the "organs of hearing," "the ears," attributing carnal things to those who cleave to the things of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:42
verses.text: Such are they of whom Micah the prophet says, "Hear the word of the Lord, ye peoples who dwell with pangs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:43
verses.text: And Abraham said, "By no means.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:44
verses.text: The Lord is He who judgeth the earth;" "since he that believeth not, is," according to the utterance of the Saviour, "condemned already".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:45
verses.text: And there is written in the Kings the judgment and sentence of the Lord, which stands thus: "The Lord hears the righteous, but the wicked He saveth not, because they do not desire to know God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:46
verses.text: For the Almighty will not accomplish what is absurd.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:47
verses.text: What do the heresies say to this utterance, seeing Scripture proclaims the Almighty God to be good, and not the author of evil and wrong, if indeed ignorance arises from one not knowing? But God does nothing absurd.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:48
verses.text: "For this God," it is said, "is our God, and there is none to save besides Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:49
verses.text: "For there is no unrighteousness  with God," according to the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:50
verses.text: And clearly yet the prophet teaches the will of God, and the gnostic proficiency, in these words: "And now, Israel, what doth the Lord God require of thee, but to fear the Lord thy God, and walk in all His ways, and love Him, and serve Him alone?" He asks of thee, who hast the power of choosing salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:51
verses.text: What is it, then, that the Pythagoreans mean when they bid us "pray with the voice"? As seems to me, not that they thought the Divinity could not hear those who speak silently, but because they wished prayers to be right, which no one would be ashamed to make in the knowledge of many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:52
verses.text: We shall, however, treat of prayer in due course by and by.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:53
verses.text: But we ought to have works that cry aloud, as becoming "those who walk in the day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book IV 26:54
verses.text: "Let thy works shine," and behold a man and his works before his face.
